name: Carrier
title: Danaos steps into LNG with Alaska project tie-up - Splash247
description:
Greek owner Danaos is widening its reach beyond boxships and bulkers after striking a strategic partnership with US energy infrastructure player Glenfarne Group on the Alaska LNG project.
Under the agreement, Danaos would construct and operate the LNG carriers that will ship cargoes from Alaska to global markets once the project moves into its export phase.
Glenfarne is developing Alaska LNG in two standalone stages.
Phase two adds liquefaction and export infrastructure designed to handle up to 20m tonnes per annum of LNG.
Glenfarne holds a 75% stake in Alaska LNG, with the Alaska Gasline Development Corporation owning the remaining 25%.
text:
Greek owner Danaos is widening its reach beyond boxships and bulkers after striking a strategic partnership with US energy infrastructure player Glenfarne Group on the Alaska LNG project.

The Nasdaq-listed company said it will invest $50m in development capital through Glenfarne Alaska Partners, while also lining up as the preferred tonnage provider for at least six LNG carrier newbuilds to support the export phase of the project.

Under the agreement, Danaos would construct and operate the LNG carriers that will ship cargoes from Alaska to global markets once the project moves into its export phase.

Glenfarne is developing Alaska LNG in two standalone stages. Phase one centres on a 765-mile pipeline from Alaska’s North Slope to supply the state’s domestic gas demand. Phase two adds liquefaction and export infrastructure designed to handle up to 20m tonnes per annum of LNG.

Glenfarne took over as lead developer of Alaska LNG in March last year and has since secured preliminary offtake commitments for around 11m tpa from buyers in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand. The project’s partner list also includes Baker Hughes and POSCO International. Glenfarne holds a 75% stake in Alaska LNG, with the Alaska Gasline Development Corporation owning the remaining 25%.

For Danaos, the move marks a step into LNG shipping and energy-linked investments, adding another leg to a business best known for its containership exposure.

Chief executive John Coustas said the project opens up a new supply source for the North Pacific and gives Danaos an opportunity to deploy its shipping expertise in LNG transportation.

The deal comes as Danaos continues to build out its wider fleet. The company currently controls 75 containerships and has more than 20 newbuildings on order. It has also been expanding in dry bulk, recently confirming the purchase of a capesize bulker due for delivery in late first-quarter 2026, taking its capesize fleet to 11 ships.

name: Air Liquide
title: Danaos to invest $50m in Alaska LNG, signs fleet deal - gasworld
authors: gasworld, Molly Burgess, Dominic Ellis, www.gasworld.com, molly-burgess
description:
Danaos Corporation, one of the world’s largest independent container ship owners, has announced a $50m investment in the 20 million tonnes per annum Alaska LNG project.
The investment will be made through Glenfarne Alaska Partners, while the LNG carriers will be built and operated for Glenfarne Alaska LNG, the project’s majority owner and developer.
Alaska LNG is majority-owned by energy infrastructure specialist Glenfarne Alaska.
Glenfarne is developing Alaska LNG in two financially independent phases to accelerate project execution.
John Coustas, CEO of Danaos, said the partnership allows the company to expand its footprint in the LNG and energy segments.
text:
Danaos Corporation, one of the world’s largest independent container ship owners, has announced a $50m investment in the 20 million tonnes per annum Alaska LNG project.

The investment will be made through Glenfarne Alaska Partners, while the LNG carriers will be built and operated for Glenfarne Alaska LNG, the project’s majority owner and developer.

Greece-based Danaos will also serve as the preferred provider of at least six liquefied natural gas carriers for the project.

Alaska LNG is majority-owned by energy infrastructure specialist Glenfarne Alaska.

Glenfarne is developing Alaska LNG in two financially independent phases to accelerate project execution. The first phase consists of a 765-mile pipeline to transport natural gas from Alaska’s North Slope to meet Alaska’s domestic energy needs.

The second phase will add the LNG terminal and related infrastructure to enable LNG export capability. The final investment decision for this element is expected in late 2026.

John Coustas, CEO of Danaos, said the partnership allows the company to expand its footprint in the LNG and energy segments.

text:
Clermont-Ferrand, January 21st, 2026

COMPAGNIE GÉNÉRALE DES ÉTABLISSEMENTS MICHELIN

Michelin appoints Bénédicte de Bonnechose as Chief Financial Officer effective June 1, 2026

Mrs. Bénédicte de Bonnechose will be appointed Chief Financial Officer of the Michelin Group, effective June 1, 2026. She will succeed Mr. Yves Chapot in this role.

A member of the Michelin Executive Committee since January 1, 2021, Bénédicte de Bonnechose currently supervises the Urban and Long-Distance Transportation Business lines, as well as the European region. She joined the Michelin Group in April 2019 as Deputy Group Chief Financial Officer.

Previously, after four years at the audit firm Deloitte working in the Industrial and Retail sectors, Bénédicte de Bonnechose built a career of over 25 years within the Lafarge Group in financial roles, before moving into business and operational leadership positions in the Cement, Aggregates, and Concrete divisions, beginning in 2007. From 2015 to 2018, Bénédicte de Bonnechose was President of LafargeHolcim France and Belgium.

name: L’Oréal
title: L'Oréal to invest $383 million in Indian beauty tech hub - Yahoo Finance
description:
In this article: (Corrects spelling of L’Oréal in headline and text) Jan 21 (Reuters) - French cosmetics giant ​L’Oréal said on Wednesday it will set ‌up a beauty tech hub in the south Indian ‌city of Hyderabad with an initial investment of over 35 billion rupees ($383.4 million).
The hub aims to be a global base for AI‑driven beauty ⁠innovation, create 2,000 ‌tech jobs through 2030, and speed up the rollout of advanced AI ‍beauty solutions, the company said in a statement.
Nicolas Hieronimus, L’Oréal CEO, and the state government of ​Telangana formalized the partnership at the World ‌Economic Forum, Davos.
Telangana has rapidly emerged as a key investment and technology hub in southern India.
($1 = 91.2860 Indian rupees) (Reporting by Urvi Dugar and Haripriya ‌Suresh in Bengaluru; Editing by Nivedita ‌Bhattacharjee and Mrigank Dhaniwala) Recommended Stories
text:
In this article:

(Corrects spelling of L’Oréal in headline and text)

Jan 21 (Reuters) - French cosmetics giant ​L’Oréal said on Wednesday it will set ‌up a beauty tech hub in the south Indian ‌city of Hyderabad with an initial investment of over 35 billion rupees ($383.4 million).

The hub aims to be a global base for AI‑driven beauty ⁠innovation, create 2,000 ‌tech jobs through 2030, and speed up the rollout of advanced AI ‍beauty solutions, the company said in a statement.

Nicolas Hieronimus, L’Oréal CEO, and the state government of ​Telangana formalized the partnership at the World ‌Economic Forum, Davos.

Telangana has rapidly emerged as a key investment and technology hub in southern India.

Bilateral trade between India and France stood at $15 billion in 2024, and Indian Prime Minister ⁠Narendra Modi and French President ​Emmanuel Macron have been ​forging warmer ties.

The two sides have also been working to recast their tax ‍treaty since ⁠2024 to modernize it by adapting global standards on tax transparency, Reuters reported in ⁠December.

($1 = 91.2860 Indian rupees)

(Reporting by Urvi Dugar and Haripriya ‌Suresh in Bengaluru; Editing by Nivedita ‌Bhattacharjee and Mrigank Dhaniwala)

title: Keysight Technologies Inc. Stock Outperforms Competitors Despite Losses On The Day
description:
Shares of Keysight Technologies Inc. (KEYS) fell 1.05% to $211.96 on a challenging trading day, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones also declined.
This marks the second consecutive day of losses for Keysight, which is now 2.84% below its 52-week high of $218.15.
Despite the downturn, Keysight outperformed competitors like Emerson Electric, Agilent Technologies, and Rockwell Automation, all of which saw larger declines.
Trading volume was below the 50-day average.

name: L’Oréal
title: L'Oréal to invest Rs 3,500 cr in Hyderabad Global Capability Centre - Awaz The Voice
description:
Hyderabad French personal care giant L’Oréal announced plans to invest Rs 3,500 crore (350 million euros) over the next five years in Telangana, with its new Global Capability Centre (GCC) set to be inaugurated in Hyderabad this November.
The company said the Hyderabad GCC will create around 2,000 highly skilled jobs, including positions for AI specialists, data scientists, and technology engineers.
The hub is expected to accelerate the development of AI-driven beauty products and services, positioning Hyderabad as a key centre for global digital operations.
The centre will function as L’Oréal’s innovation, technology, data, and supply chain hub, supporting the company’s global digital transformation.
The new hub will operate alongside L’Oréal’s global technology network in countries including France, the US, China, Singapore, Spain, Poland, Canada, Brazil, and Mexico.
text:
Hyderabad

French personal care giant L’Oréal announced plans to invest Rs 3,500 crore (350 million euros) over the next five years in Telangana, with its new Global Capability Centre (GCC) set to be inaugurated in Hyderabad this November. The facility will focus on advanced beauty-tech solutions, artificial intelligence, and digital innovation.

The company said the Hyderabad GCC will create around 2,000 highly skilled jobs, including positions for AI specialists, data scientists, and technology engineers. The hub is expected to accelerate the development of AI-driven beauty products and services, positioning Hyderabad as a key centre for global digital operations.

L’Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus made the announcement on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland. He described the GCC as “the world’s first Beauty Tech Hub of its kind,” serving as a flagship for AI-powered beauty innovations. “With an initial investment of over Rs 3,500 crore through 2030, this hub will become a global powerhouse, integrating AI, generative AI, and other emerging technologies,” Hieronimus said.

The centre will function as L’Oréal’s innovation, technology, data, and supply chain hub, supporting the company’s global digital transformation. Telangana Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy welcomed the investment, highlighting its alignment with the state’s “Telangana Rising: 2047 Vision” and the creation of high-value jobs. “This decision reflects the confidence global leaders have in Telangana’s innovation ecosystem and talent pool,” he said.

Industry Minister D. Sridhar Babu noted that Hyderabad’s selection for the GCC was a “strong endorsement” of the state’s ability to attract leading global companies. He added that the state government is committed to extending full support to L’Oréal and other international investors.

Hieronimus emphasized India’s strategic role in the company’s global plans, citing over three decades of L’Oréal’s presence in the country. “The future of beauty lies at the intersection of science, technology, and creativity. Hyderabad will now sit at the heart of our AI and digital ambitions,” he said.

The new hub will operate alongside L’Oréal’s global technology network in countries including France, the US, China, Singapore, Spain, Poland, Canada, Brazil, and Mexico. Officials said the GCC will foster collaboration across L’Oréal’s global teams to co-create innovations for the beauty industry.

Telangana’s Special Chief Secretary (Industries) Sanjay Kumar also invited L’Oréal to explore potential manufacturing opportunities in Hyderabad, in addition to the GCC investment. Hieronimus expressed interest in expanding the company’s footprint in the state, signaling further potential investments in the near future.

ALSO READ: Kabir Khan's film on the Taj Mahal turns into India's soft power

The Hyderabad GCC inauguration is scheduled for November 2026, with Chief Minister Revanth Reddy and Minister Sridhar Babu invited to attend.

name: OpenAI
title: Gates and OpenAI team up for AI health push in African countries | Reuters
description:
LONDON, Jan 21 (Reuters) - The Gates Foundation and OpenAI are setting up a $50 million partnership to help African countries use artificial intelligence to improve their health systems.
"In poorer countries with enormous health worker shortages and lack of health systems infrastructure, AI can be a gamechanger in expanding access to quality care," said Gates in a blog post announcing the launch.
The foundation has already set up a number of AI initiatives, while Rwanda last year established an AI health hub in Kigali.
Horizon1000 aims to reach 1,000 primary health clinics and surrounding communities across several countries by 2028, Gates said.
AI could be particularly valuable in countries with severe shortages of trained health workers, Gates said.
text:
LONDON, Jan 21 (Reuters) - The Gates Foundation and OpenAI are setting up a $50 million partnership to help African countries use artificial intelligence to improve their health systems.

The partnership, called Horizon1000, plans to work with African leaders to work out how best to use the technology, starting with Rwanda.

Keep up with the latest medical breakthroughs and healthcare trends with the Reuters Health Rounds newsletter. Sign up here.

"In poorer countries with enormous health worker shortages and lack of health systems infrastructure, AI can be a gamechanger in expanding access to quality care," said Gates in a blog post announcing the launch. He has repeatedly described AI as one of the most transformative technologies ever developed.

The foundation has already set up a number of AI initiatives, while Rwanda last year established an AI health hub in Kigali.

Horizon1000 aims to reach 1,000 primary health clinics and surrounding communities across several countries by 2028, Gates said.

The launch comes as many lower-income countries struggle with major cuts to international aid budgets - reductions Gates said in December had contributed to the first rise in preventable child deaths this century.

AI could be particularly valuable in countries with severe shortages of trained health workers, Gates said. He noted estimates suggesting sub-Saharan Africa is short of around six million healthcare professionals.

Reporting by Jennifer Rigby. Editing by Mark Potter

Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab

Jen is the Global Health Correspondent at Reuters, covering everything from pandemics to the rise of obesity worldwide. Since joining the news agency in 2022, her award-winning work includes coverage of gender-affirming care for adolescents in the UK and a global investigation with colleagues into how contaminated cough syrup killed hundreds of children in Africa and Asia. She previously worked at the Telegraph newspaper and Channel 4 News in the UK, and spent time as a freelancer in Myanmar and the Czech Republic.

name: Barclays
title: FTSE 100 Little Changed on Wednesday - Trading Economics
description:
The FTSE 100 was little changed on Wednesday, stabilising after this week’s tariff driven selloff as market volatility eased and investors digested fresh inflation data.
UK inflation rose more than expected to 3.4%, while core CPI was in line and services inflation increased less than forecast, offering mixed signals for policy expectations.
Banks weighed on the index, with HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds, NatWest and Standard Chartered all falling, alongside declines in AstraZeneca, RELX, Rolls Royce and BAE Systems.
Losses were partly offset by strength in miners and precious metals stocks, with Endeavour Mining, Rio Tinto, Anglo American, Antofagasta and Glencore rising on firmer metals prices.
Among individual movers, Burberry climbed more than 4% after third quarter sales beat expectations.
text:
The FTSE 100 was little changed on Wednesday, stabilising after this week’s tariff driven selloff as market volatility eased and investors digested fresh inflation data.

UK inflation rose more than expected to 3.4%, while core CPI was in line and services inflation increased less than forecast, offering mixed signals for policy expectations.

Banks weighed on the index, with HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds, NatWest and Standard Chartered all falling, alongside declines in AstraZeneca, RELX, Rolls Royce and BAE Systems.

Losses were partly offset by strength in miners and precious metals stocks, with Endeavour Mining, Rio Tinto, Anglo American, Antofagasta and Glencore rising on firmer metals prices.

Among individual movers, Burberry climbed more than 4% after third quarter sales beat expectations.

JD Sports also advanced nearly 2% after saying profits are set to meet estimates.

In contrast, Experian dropped almost 5% despite beating revenue forecasts.

name: Adobe
title: 'Agentic Web Will Transform How Brands Are Perceived,' Says Adobe Executive
authors: Outlook Business Desk, Outlook Start-Up Desk
description:
With user search now shifting towards an agentic web, the World Wide Web is no longer what it once was.
“Brands should recognise that they are now building for both humans and AI.
Without this, brands risk not being accurately represented in AI-driven environments,” said Venugopalan.
What brands need are guided and trusted conversations when users finally arrive on their apps or websites,” he added.
Further, with AI lowering entry barriers, he said that when it comes to content, quality now matters more than quantity.
text:
With user search now shifting towards an agentic web, the World Wide Web is no longer what it once was. As a result, it has become important for brands to build digital experiences not just for humans but also for AI, as per Vyshak Venugopalan, Senior Director, India & JAPAC Partner at Adobe India. While this is worrying for brands, as they lose some control over how they are represented, it also means they must adapt to how discovery is changing.

“Brands should recognise that they are now building for both humans and AI. This is not the end of SEO; it is about combining SEO with generative optimisation. Without this, brands risk not being accurately represented in AI-driven environments,” said Venugopalan.

There are risks here. If a company’s content is not structured and AI-readable, their brand can be misrepresented, as per Venugopalan. “We have already seen this happen to platforms that once dominated user journeys. Revenue models are changing because consumer opinions are being shaped elsewhere. What brands need are guided and trusted conversations when users finally arrive on their apps or websites,” he added.

Further, with AI lowering entry barriers, he said that when it comes to content, quality now matters more than quantity. He added that while the demand for content has grown exponentially, it also goes stale far more quickly than it did even six months ago.

If a company has eight products, once you factor in channels, languages, and formats, this can translate into hundreds of thousands of content assets, he added. “Many enterprises are unprepared for this. Creating content that is authentic, structured, brand-aligned, and scalable is very different from producing generic material,” he further explained.

This means companies must assess whether they have a content supply chain that is AI-accelerated but human-led. While AI can generate volume, human oversight is essential to ensure brand integrity. According to Venugopalan, this is a journey rather than a quick fix and requires a clear roadmap to create content that is efficient, cost-effective, compelling, and conversion-driven.

text:
What Kraft Heinz’s Recent Returns May Signal for Investors

Kraft Heinz (KHC) has seen its share price under pressure recently, with negative returns over the past month, past 3 months, year to date, and past year, even as annual revenue and net income figures remain positive.

At a share price of $23.76, Kraft Heinz’s momentum looks muted, with a 30 day share price return of a 3.06% decline and a 1 year total shareholder return of a 14.58% loss, pointing to fading enthusiasm despite positive annual revenue and net income figures.

If this kind of mixed performance has you looking around the market, it could be a good moment to broaden your search with .

With Kraft Heinz trading at $23.76 and indicators like analyst targets and intrinsic value estimates suggesting a discount, the key question is whether this is a genuine value opportunity or whether the market already sees limited future growth.

Price-to-Sales of 1.1x: Is it justified?

On a P/S of 1.1x at a share price of $23.76, Kraft Heinz screens as good value against peers in some checks, but looks more expensive in others.

The P/S ratio compares what investors are paying for each dollar of revenue. It is often used for companies where earnings are weak or volatile. For Kraft Heinz, this tilt toward sales-based metrics fits with its current unprofitable status and the reliance on future earnings improvement rather than present profits.

Against its own fair P/S estimate of 1.3x, Kraft Heinz trades at a lower level. This suggests the market price is sitting below where our fair ratio work indicates it could settle. Yet when you stack that 1.1x P/S next to the broader US Food industry average of 0.8x, the stock looks more expensive than many peers, hinting that investors are still assigning a premium even with recent share price pressure.

Result: Price-to-Sales of 1.1x (ABOUT RIGHT)

However, you also need to weigh risks such as Kraft Heinz’s recent net income loss of $4.4b and a 30.7% three-year total shareholder return decline.

Another View: What the SWS DCF Model Suggests

While the P/S of 1.1x makes Kraft Heinz look roughly in line with its fair ratio work, our DCF model points in a different direction. It estimates future cash flows at $68.79 per share versus today’s $23.76 price, which flags a sizeable potential undervaluation.

That kind of gap can signal either an opportunity or that the cash flow assumptions are too optimistic, so it is worth asking which story you think fits Kraft Heinz better, and why.

Approximately 218,312,412 shares were traded during trading, an increase of 29% from the average daily volume of 169,643,531 shares. The stock had previously closed at $186.23.

AMD Rebound Begins: It’s Not Too Late to Get In

Neutral Sentiment: NVIDIA’s Arm‑based N1/N1X laptop SoCs are reportedly set to debut in 2026 — a potential new market but not an immediate large revenue driver compared with data center sales. Read More.

Negative Sentiment: China appears to be holding up approvals/shipments of the H200 AI chip; suppliers reportedly paused output — a direct revenue/shipments headwind for NVDA in the China market. Read More.

Hedge funds and other institutional investors own 65.27% of the company's stock.

About NVIDIA

(Get Free Report)

NVIDIA Corporation, founded in 1993 and headquartered in Santa Clara, California, is a global technology company that designs and develops graphics processing units (GPUs) and system-on-chip (SoC) technologies. Co-founded by Jensen Huang, who serves as president and chief executive officer, along with Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem, NVIDIA has grown from a graphics-focused chipmaker into a broad provider of accelerated computing hardware and software for multiple industries.

The company's product portfolio spans discrete GPUs for gaming and professional visualization (marketed under the GeForce and NVIDIA RTX lines), high-performance data center accelerators used for AI training and inference (including widely adopted platforms such as the A100 and H100 series), and Tegra SoCs for automotive and edge applications.

name: Delta Airlines
title: Delta Air Lines Announces Major Ticketing Change in a First for U.S. Airlines - Yahoo Finance
description:
Delta Air Lines has already offered a Basic tier for its main cabin seating for over a decade, giving budget-conscious customers an opportunity to shed extras in favor of lower base fares.
Now, that option is coming to its premium cabins as well.
Delta is also set to offer an Extra tier for its premium cabins, mirroring a tier already offered in its Main cabin.
As The New York Times reported, Delta planned to have premium-cabin revenue supplant main cabin by 2027.
The introduction of Basic fares like Delta offers is largely credited with the shift, and it seems likely that new Business and First class ticketing tiers are likely to further shake up the economics of air travel.
text:
Delta Air Lines has already offered a Basic tier for its main cabin seating for over a decade, giving budget-conscious customers an opportunity to shed extras in favor of lower base fares. Now, that option is coming to its premium cabins as well.

The airline revealed during a Q4 earnings call last week that it will soon begin offering tiered fares for both Business and First class, becoming the first U.S.-based airline to do so.

Although the details have not yet been revealed, it's likely that these fares will operate similar to Basic Economy, which unbundles the airline seat itself from other perks like lounge access, seat selection, and the ability to earn SkyMiles. An exact timeline has not been announced, but the company plans to launch the new offerings sometime this year.

Delta is also set to offer an Extra tier for its premium cabins, mirroring a tier already offered in its Main cabin. The Extra Economy tier currently offers boarding and SkyMiles upgrades as well as increased ticketing flexibility.

No other U.S. airline currently offers lower-cost options for its premium cabins, although international carriers like Qatar Airways, Emirates, and Etihad offer similar products for their Business class fares.

Airline President Outlines New Strategy

Delta President Glen Hauenstein said in the call that the airline plans to offer “three categories for every product, which is basic, main, and extra.”

Hauenstein explained his reasoning, saying passengers will appreciate the added flexibility across all of its cabins.

“I think that if you were offered a $500 ticket, there was no reason for you to ever want to pay more than $500 because it was fully loaded," he said. "Now that seat is $500, but you can buy it for $450 if you’re willing to get the seat assignment at 48 hours, if you’re willing to have it non-refundable, and then all the way up to extra where it’s fully refundable and you get the best seats unlocked at that time."

Ticket Update Comes Amid Changing Airline Economics

Delta's decision to offer both pared-back and premium options for all its tickets comes as the economics of air travel have changed. The airline sold over a billion dollars less in main cabin tickets last year, but still had its most profitable year ever due to jumps in business and first class ticket sales as well as co-branded credit cards. As The New York Times reported, Delta planned to have premium-cabin revenue supplant main cabin by 2027. It ended up happening by 2025, two years earlier than projected.

Meanwhile, budget airlines like Spirit and Frontier are struggling. Spirit continues to teeter on the verge of bankruptcy, while low-cost carriers Sun Country Airlines and Avelo Airlines recently announced plans to merge in order to better compete against its larger rivals. The introduction of Basic fares like Delta offers is largely credited with the shift, and it seems likely that new Business and First class ticketing tiers are likely to further shake up the economics of air travel.

name: L’Oréal
title: `Telangana Rising': L'Oréal to launch world's first beauty-tech GCC in Hyderabad in Nov
description:
Davos: Global cosmetics leader, L'Oréal, has announced it will inaugurate the world's first beauty-tech Global Capability Centre (GCC) in Hyderabad.
The announcement followed a meeting at the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2026 between L'Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus and the `Telangana Rising’ delegation, led by Chief Minister A Revanth Reddy.
A Global Nerve Center for Digital Transformation The Hyderabad GCC will not merely serve regional interests but will act as the digital backbone for L'Oréal’s global operations.
What is a Beauty-Tech GCC?
To understand the scale of this investment, it helps to look at the "Beauty-Tech" ecosystem L'Oréal has been building.
text:
Davos: Global cosmetics leader, L'Oréal, has announced it will inaugurate the world's first beauty-tech Global Capability Centre (GCC) in Hyderabad.

Scheduled for a November 2026 opening, the facility marks a significant shift in how beauty giants integrate technology. Rather than a traditional administrative office, this hub is designed as a global powerhouse for innovation, data science, and supply chain logistics.

The announcement followed a meeting at the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2026 between L'Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus and the `Telangana Rising’ delegation, led by Chief Minister A Revanth Reddy.

A Global Nerve Center for Digital Transformation

The Hyderabad GCC will not merely serve regional interests but will act as the digital backbone for L'Oréal’s global operations. CEO Nicolas Hieronimus highlighted that the solutions developed in Telangana—ranging from Artificial Intelligence (AI) to advanced data analytics—will be exported to L'Oréal facilities worldwide. "This facility will support our digital transformation on a global scale. Tech solutions generated here in Hyderabad will be supplied to our facilities all around the world," Hieronimus explained during the summit.

Highlights of the Strategic Discussion

The meeting between the Telangana delegation and L'Oréal leadership covered several key pillars of growth:

The Beauty-Tech Niche: Minister D Sridhar Babu emphasized that while Hyderabad is already a leader in med-tech and health-tech, L'Oréal’s entry creates an entirely new category—Beauty-Tech—expanding the state’s GCC portfolio.

The AI Connection: The delegation presented the newly launched Telangana AI Innovation Hub (TAIH). Hieronimus expressed a strong interest in the hub, noting that AI is central to L'Oréal’s future strategy for personalized beauty and virtual "try-on" experiences.

Future Manufacturing: Beyond the tech hub, special chief secretary Sanjay Kumar formally invited L'Oréal to establish a manufacturing unit in the state. Citing Telangana’s robust infrastructure and existing ecosystem, the proposal was met with a positive response, with L'Oréal agreeing to explore future investments in local production.

A Growing Ecosystem: The Minister noted that L'Oréal joins an elite group of global giants—including Netflix, Vanguard, and Marriott—that have recently chosen Hyderabad as their global base.

What is a Beauty-Tech GCC?

To understand the scale of this investment, it helps to look at the "Beauty-Tech" ecosystem L'Oréal has been building. The Hyderabad center is expected to focus on:

Hyper-personalization: Using AI to analyze skin and hair types for custom product recommendations

Smart Supply Chain: Real-time data tracking to optimize global distribution and reduce carbon footprints

Augmented Reality: Developing the next generation of virtual makeup and hair color testing tools

Big Data: Analyzing global consumer trends to predict the next big beauty movements

Looking Ahead

Chief Minister A Revanth Reddy and Minister D Sridhar Babu have been officially invited to lead the inauguration ceremony in November 2026. This partnership solidifies Hyderabad’s reputation as a "plug-and-play" destination for global tech, proving that the city is no longer just for IT services, but a premier destination for specialized, high-tech innovation.

text:
Brand loyalty recognition and sustainability push as an investment trigger

Levi Strauss (LEVI) has drawn fresh investor attention after topping a major apparel brand loyalty ranking and rolling out its Wear Longer Project, a national program centered on clothing repair, customization, and sustainability education.

Despite the positive brand news, Levi Strauss’ recent share price performance has been subdued, with a 1-day share price return decline of 3.68% and a 30-day share price return decline of 3.45%. At the same time, the 1-year total shareholder return of 23.02% and 3-year total shareholder return of 36.90% point to momentum that has built over a longer stretch.

If brand strength and sustainability are on your radar, this could be a good moment to widen the lens and check out as another corner of the market to research.

With Levi Strauss posting a 1-year total shareholder return of 23.02%, trading at $20.96, and sitting at roughly a 30% discount to the average analyst price target, you have to ask: is there real value here, or is the market already baking in future growth?

Price to earnings of 15.7x, is it justified?

At a last close of US$20.96, Levi Strauss trades on a P/E of 15.7x, which screens as good value against both its own fair P/E and key peer groups.

P/E compares the company’s share price to its earnings, so it is a quick way to see how much investors are paying for each dollar of profit. For a branded apparel group like Levi Strauss, this matters because earnings quality, return on equity and growth expectations often influence how far that multiple can stretch.

Here, the 15.7x P/E sits below the estimated fair P/E of 18x, which suggests the market price is not fully reflecting the level of earnings being generated. It also comes alongside high quality earnings, a 24.2% return on equity and earnings that grew much faster than their 5 year average. This provides some context for why a higher multiple could potentially be supported over time.

Against the wider market, the P/E appears more compressed. It is lower than the US Luxury industry average of 20.1x and well below the peer average of 31.9x. This points to a gap that could close if sentiment shifts toward companies with stronger profitability metrics.

Result: Price-to-earnings of 15.7x (UNDERVALUED)

However, you still need to weigh risks such as recent short term share price weakness, as well as the possibility that brand driven expectations outpace actual revenue and earnings trends.

Another view on value

Our DCF model points in the same direction as the P/E comparison but from a different angle. With Levi Strauss trading at US$20.96 versus an SWS DCF fair value estimate of US$25.52, the shares sit at about an 18% discount on this method as well. If both signals are pointing to value, what factors could potentially influence the story from here?

title: Kraft Heinz (KHC) Stock Falls as Berkshire Weighs Selling Entire 27.5% Stake - TipRanks
description:
Shares of Kraft Heinz (KHC) fell 3.8% in after-hours trading yesterday after a regulatory filing revealed that Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) may fully exit its stake.
Kraft Heinz filed a prospectus stating that Berkshire could sell its remaining 27.5% stake, or 325,442,152 shares.
Kraft Heinz Prepares for a Split Berkshire’s potential sale comes ahead of Kraft Heinz’s planned split in the second half of this year.
Kraft Heinz also pointed to shifting consumer tastes toward healthier foods and weak sales, including a 3% drop in 2024, as factors driving the decision.
On TipRanks, Kraft Heinz has a Hold consensus rating based on zero Buys, 13 Holds, and one Sell rating.
text:
Shares of Kraft Heinz (KHC) fell 3.8% in after-hours trading yesterday after a regulatory filing revealed that Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) may fully exit its stake. Kraft Heinz filed a prospectus stating that Berkshire could sell its remaining 27.5% stake, or 325,442,152 shares. At January 20’s closing price of $23.76, the stake is worth roughly $7.7 billion.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions

Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The packaged food giant has been struggling with sluggish sales amid a lack of innovation, underinvestment in brands, fierce competition from healthier alternatives, and rising food prices. The filing does not confirm a sale but enables the selling shareholder to dispose of its holding.

Why Is Berkshire Exiting Its Stake?

Warren Buffett first acquired shares during the 2015 merger between Kraft Foods and H.J. Heinz, alongside Brazilian private equity group 3G Capital. However, the combined company did not progress as expected. Buffett has called the investment a mistake due to excessive optimism about its prospects.

Under Buffett’s leadership, Berkshire already wrote down the KHC investment twice and took huge losses: a $3 billion write-down in 2019 and another $3.76 billion in August 2025.

Kraft Heinz Prepares for a Split

Berkshire’s potential sale comes ahead of Kraft Heinz’s planned split in the second half of this year. In September 2025, KHC announced the breakup, citing the merged company’s complex structure, which has hindered effective capital allocation, initiative prioritization, and scaling of promising areas.

The split will create two companies, one for groceries and the other for sauces and spreads, so each can focus resources better and improve results. Kraft Heinz also pointed to shifting consumer tastes toward healthier foods and weak sales, including a 3% drop in 2024, as factors driving the decision.

KHC appointed new CEO Steve Cahillane on January 1, 2026, to oversee the split, the same day when Greg Abel took over Berkshire’s helm from Buffett. Both Abel and Buffett have opposed the split, which could also be one of the reasons for Berkshire’s potential exit.

Why Is Kraft Heinz Stock So Low?

KHC stock has lost 19.4% over the past year amid ongoing challenges. On TipRanks, Kraft Heinz has a Hold consensus rating based on zero Buys, 13 Holds, and one Sell rating. The average Kraft Heinz price target of $25.38 implies 6.8% upside potential from current levels.

See more KHC analyst ratings

name: L’Oréal
title: L'Oréal Sets Up First Global Tech Hub in Hyderabad, ₹3,500 Cr Investment - Whalesbook
description:
TECH Overview French beauty giant L'Oréal is launching its inaugural global technology hub in Hyderabad, India.
This strategic development places India at the forefront of L'Oréal's global digital and AI strategy, leveraging local talent for AI-led solutions and digital platforms.
This collaboration centers on establishing the company's first global Beauty Tech Hub in Hyderabad.
This Hyderabad facility is set to become the company's sole global hub dedicated to beauty technology.
The Telangana government views this establishment as aligning seamlessly with its own Telangana AI Hub, designed to foster applied AI and advanced data engineering.
text:
TECH

Overview

French beauty giant L'Oréal is launching its inaugural global technology hub in Hyderabad, India. The move signals a substantial ₹3,500 crore investment through 2030, aiming to create 2,000 tech roles. This strategic development places India at the forefront of L'Oréal's global digital and AI strategy, leveraging local talent for AI-led solutions and digital platforms.

French beauty conglomerate L'Oréal has formalized its strategic partnership with the Government of Telangana. This collaboration centers on establishing the company's first global Beauty Tech Hub in Hyderabad.

The agreement, formalized at the World Economic Forum in Davos, outlines a significant investment exceeding ₹3,500 crore through 2030. L'Oréal plans to create approximately 2,000 high-value technology roles over this period.

Investment and Job Creation

These positions will span AI specialists, engineers, and data professionals, bolstering the company's capabilities in data, artificial intelligence, and generative AI. This Hyderabad facility is set to become the company's sole global hub dedicated to beauty technology.

India at the Forefront of AI Strategy

The hub will operate as a key node within L'Oréal's international technology and AI network, supporting global teams in developing and scaling digital tools and platforms. This move significantly elevates India's role in the company's overarching technology and services roadmap.

State Government Collaboration

Telangana Chief Minister Revanth Reddy stated the partnership directly supports the state's "Telangana Rising: 2047 Vision" by generating jobs and positioning the state as an AI and digital excellence epicenter. The initiative also aligns with the 2026 India-France Year of Innovation.

Global Network Integration

L'Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus highlighted the group's 31-year commitment to India, emphasizing the harnessing of local tech and AI expertise. He posited that Hyderabad will now be central to the company's digital ambition, aiming to invent the future of beauty.

The Telangana government views this establishment as aligning seamlessly with its own Telangana AI Hub, designed to foster applied AI and advanced data engineering. This reinforces a global trend where multinational corporations increasingly leverage Indian talent and infrastructure for large-scale digital transformation.

name: L’Oréal
title: L'Oréal to set up its first global tech hub in Hyderabad, announces at WEF 2026
description:
Hyderabad: L’Oréal has announced the launch of its first global Tech Hub in Hyderabad, India, marking a significant milestone in its AI-powered Beauty Tech ambition.
Billed as the first Beauty Tech hub of its kind globally, the Hyderabad facility will serve as a flagship centre for developing the next generation of AI-powered beauty innovation and services.
By establishing the hub in Hyderabad, L’Oréal aims to contribute to Telangana’s growing stature as a centre for digital excellence and high-value technology talent.
Building on this legacy, we are harnessing India’s world-class tech and AI engineering expertise to power our new global Tech Hub.
The establishment of L’Oréal’s Global Tech Hub aligns seamlessly with our newly formed Telangana AI Hub, which is designed to serve as a catalyst for applied AI, advanced data engineering, and next-generation digital capabilities.
text:
Hyderabad: L’Oréal has announced the launch of its first global Tech Hub in Hyderabad, India, marking a significant milestone in its AI-powered Beauty Tech ambition. The announcement was made following a high-level meeting at the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2026 between D. Sridhar Babu, Hon’ble Minister for IT, Electronics & Industries, Sanjay Kumar, Special Chief Secretary, Government of Telangana, and Nicolas Hieronimus, CEO of L’Oréal.

Billed as the first Beauty Tech hub of its kind globally, the Hyderabad facility will serve as a flagship centre for developing the next generation of AI-powered beauty innovation and services. With an initial investment of over ₹3,500 crores (€350 million) through 2030, the hub will focus on Data, AI, Generative AI, Agentic AI, and other emerging technologies. It is expected to create 2,000 highly skilled jobs, including roles for AI specialists, tech engineers, and data scientists, while accelerating the global deployment of AI-led beauty solutions at scale.

The partnership between L’Oréal and the Government of Telangana was formalised at Davos and stands as a key milestone in the 2026 India–France Year of Innovation. Beyond infrastructure investment, the collaboration emphasises talent development and upskilling, with the vision of building “from India, for the world” AI-driven beauty solutions. By establishing the hub in Hyderabad, L’Oréal aims to contribute to Telangana’s growing stature as a centre for digital excellence and high-value technology talent.

The India Tech Hub will also play a strategic role within L’Oréal’s integrated global AI and Tech ecosystem, complementing existing hubs in France, the USA, China, Singapore, Spain, Poland, Canada, Brazil, and Mexico. Together, these centres are designed to foster global collaboration and co-create the future of Beauty Tech.

Welcoming the development, Revanth Reddy, Hon’ble Chief Minister of Telangana, said, “We are delighted that L’Oréal has chosen Hyderabad for its new global tech hub, a decision that reflects the deep confidence global leaders place in Telangana’s innovation ecosystem and highly skilled talent pool. This partnership directly supports our ‘Telangana Rising: 2047 Vision’ by creating 2,000 high-value jobs and positioning our state as a global epicentre for AI and digital excellence.”

Nicolas Hieronimus, CEO, L’Oréal, said, “For over 31 years, L’Oréal has been deeply committed to India. Building on this legacy, we are harnessing India’s world-class tech and AI engineering expertise to power our new global Tech Hub. We believe that the future of beauty lies at the intersection of science, technology and creativity, so Hyderabad will now sit at the heart of our AI and digital ambition. This first-of-its-kind Beauty Tech Hub reinforces our commitment to India’s growth and our leading role in the 2026 India-France Year of Innovation.”

D. Sridhar Babu, Hon’ble Minister for IT, Electronics & Industries, Government of Telangana, added, “L’Oréal’s decision to establish its new global tech hub in Hyderabad is a powerful endorsement of Telangana’s ability to attract world-leading innovation. This collaboration exemplifies the ‘Telangana Rising: 2047 Vision’ — a vision where global enterprises co-create next-generation technology with our extraordinary local talent. By aligning beauty with cutting-edge AI, data, and engineering, L’Oréal is not only shaping the future of its industry but also contributing to our state’s journey as a global hub for digital excellence and innovation-led growth.”

Sanjay Kumar, Special Chief Secretary, Government of Telangana, said, “Telangana is executing a clear and deliberate strategy to accelerate AI adoption at scale—across government, industry, and society. The establishment of L’Oréal’s Global Tech Hub aligns seamlessly with our newly formed Telangana AI Hub, which is designed to serve as a catalyst for applied AI, advanced data engineering, and next-generation digital capabilities. Together, these initiatives reinforce Hyderabad’s position as a global center where cutting-edge AI innovation is built, deployed, and scaled for the world.”

With this announcement, L’Oréal has reaffirmed India’s role as a strategic partner in its global transformation journey, positioning Indian innovation at the forefront of shaping the next frontier of beauty.

name: OpenAI
title: OpenAI inks deal with ServiceNow to integrate AI model - LinkedIn
description:
Within our teams, this includes emerging roles such as: * The AI Finance Strategist, who understands the business strategies and identifies key opportunities in finance for execution through AI.
When AI models commoditize, differentiation comes from everything around the models.
OpenAI and ServiceNow’s three-year deal embeds AI models and agents directly into enterprise workflow software.
ServiceNow made a revenue commitment to OpenAI; customers will access OpenAI intelligence within ServiceNow platforms.
ServiceNow customers should expect an accelerated push to get adoption and usage of ServiceNow "AI" offerings.
text:
Technology alone doesn’t make a team AI-native—people do. At ServiceNow, we’re actively realigning our Finance & Strategy organization for an AI-native future. As AI becomes embedded in how decisions are made, our workforce must evolve just as quickly. For us, AI fluency is now table stakes. Every role in Finance & Strategy must confidently leverage agentic tools—from research platforms and summarization engines to forecasting copilots and modeling assistants—to accelerate insight and execution. But fluency alone is not sufficient. The real shift is toward hybrid talent: professionals who combine deep financial and strategic judgment with the ability to work with, interrogate, and govern AI at scale. These are the architects of modern finance automation and decision-making. Within our teams, this includes emerging roles such as: * The AI Finance Strategist, who understands the business strategies and identifies key opportunities in finance for execution through AI. * The Finance Ops Specialist, who builds and implements AI workflows that power forecasting, scenario planning, and decision support. * The AI Risk Specialist, who safeguards integrity by monitoring and mitigating risks tied to AI-driven decisions. Roles like these—and many we haven’t yet imagined—will help us not only continue to adopt AI, but also shape the future of Finance & Strategy. What new or unexpected roles are you seeing emerge in your organization as AI scales?

ServiceNow just signed a three-year deal with OpenAI. This is the specialization model playing out in real time. ServiceNow is excellent at workflow platforms. OpenAI is excellent at AI models. Neither is trying to do the other's job. Each focuses on what they do best and partners for the rest. This validates what I keep hearing from vendors: "We don't have the bandwidth to build everything." ServiceNow could have tried building their own models. They have the resources. They did if I recall correctly. But building world-class AI models would pull focus from what actually differentiates them - their workflow platform and enterprise integration capabilities. OpenAI gets distribution into one of the largest enterprise software platforms without building workflow tools. ServiceNow gets leading AI models without years of R&D investment. Both win because they're not trying to own layers they don't need to own. The article (link in comments) mentions ServiceNow has similar deals with OpenAI's competitors. That's the point. They're platform-agnostic because their value isn't the AI models themselves. Their moat is the workflow layer, the data layer, and how well they integrate into enterprise operations. When AI models commoditize, differentiation comes from everything around the models. This includes the workflows, the context, and the integration quality. This is the same model Unito operates on. We specialize in the integration layer so vendors can focus on what they do best while their systems actually talk to each other. ServiceNow's partnership with OpenAI is a blueprint for how enterprise AI gets built at scale. Not by vendors trying to own the entire stack, but by specialists focusing on their layer and partnering for the rest. The vendors that figure this out will ship products people actually adopt. The ones still trying to build everything will keep struggling with complexity.

OpenAI and ServiceNow’s three-year deal embeds AI models and agents directly into enterprise workflow software. ServiceNow made a revenue commitment to OpenAI; customers will access OpenAI intelligence within ServiceNow platforms. The deal reflects AI agents becoming standard business software infrastructure, not standalone products but embedded capabilities. ∙ Distribution Strategy: OpenAI gains enterprise reach through ServiceNow’s installed base rather than selling direct. The revenue commitment structure guarantees OpenAI income while ServiceNow absorbs adoption risk—a favorable arrangement for the model maker expanding beyond consumer chatbots. ∙ Computer-Use Integration: ServiceNow will embed OpenAI’s computer-use model, enabling agents to perform IT tasks autonomously—restarting computers, accessing legacy mainframe data. This targets real enterprise pain: unlocking information trapped in old systems without costly custom integration. ∙ Voice Agent Development: ServiceNow will build customer service voice agents using OpenAI’s speech models. The workflow software + voice AI combination creates end-to-end automation for call centers and IT helpdesks—high-volume, high-cost functions ripe for agent replacement. ∙ Competitive Positioning: OpenAI faces Anthropic, Google, and Microsoft in enterprise AI. ServiceNow’s “open platform” stance—maintaining relationships with multiple model providers—means this deal provides distribution without exclusivity. OpenAI must compete on capability within ServiceNow’s multi-model environment. ∙ IT Labor Implications: The article explicitly notes AI agents will “disrupt the IT labor market, which has been in steady decline.” ServiceNow deploying “forward deployed engineers” to help customers implement automation acknowledges the product’s purpose: reducing human IT headcount through agent substitution. The partnership structure previews enterprise AI’s distribution model: workflow platforms become the surface where agents operate, model makers provide intelligence, and customers pay through existing software relationships rather than new AI contracts https://lnkd.in/ekr98TKb

It was only a matter of time, but still "newsworthy"...not quite "breaking news" worth though.. #ServiceNow's deal with #OpenAI allows them to enhance their platforms by integrating the ChatGPT-maker’s AI models into ServiceNow’s products. In other words, ServiceNow doesn't have to build out the #AI capabilities on their own. Of course, this comes at a cost...for ServiceNow and ServiceNow customers. Based on the reporting, ServiceNow has made a revenue commitment to OpenAI. Specifics were not shared, but did we expect them to be? ServiceNow customers should expect an accelerated push to get adoption and usage of ServiceNow "AI" offerings. ServiceNow customers, that have not properly protected themselves, should also expected meaningful price increases imposed come renewal time. I also fully expect this deal and partnership to be highlighted during ServiceNow's upcoming Q4 earnings call (next week) and throughout ServiceNow's annual Knowledge conference in May. #negotiation https://lnkd.in/egi6sDnu

Boston Scientific (NYSE:BSX) announced a $14.5b agreement to acquire Penumbra, expanding into neurovascular and mechanical thrombectomy markets.

The company also agreed to acquire Valencia Technologies, adding the FDA approved eCoin System for overactive bladder to its Urology portfolio.

Both deals mark some of the largest transactions for Boston Scientific in recent years and target underpenetrated medical device segments.

Boston Scientific comes into these acquisitions with shares at $91.2 and a long run of strong multi year returns, including 99.0% over 3 years and 148.9% over 5 years. Recent performance has been softer, with a 9.6% decline over 1 year and smaller declines over the past week, month and year to date, so investors may be watching how these transactions influence sentiment.

For shareholders and potential investors, a central consideration is how effectively Boston Scientific can integrate Penumbra and Valencia Technologies and scale the new platforms. The deals meaningfully widen NYSE:BSX exposure to neurovascular, thrombectomy and urology devices, so future updates on regulatory, clinical and commercial execution around these assets are likely to be important catalysts.

name: Barclays

title: Barclays warns Greenland tensions pose greater risk to euro than dollar - investingLive
description:
Barclays sees Greenland-related geopolitical risks as a bigger long-term threat to the euro than the dollar despite near-term USD weakness.
Summary: The dollar weakened as Greenland tensions and tariff threats escalated.
Barclays warns euro faces greater risk in a severe US–EU fallout.
NATO cohesion and European defence spending are key concerns.
While the greenback softened on the day, some strategists argue the longer-term risks from a deterioration in US–Europe relations may fall more heavily on the euro.
text:
Barclays sees Greenland-related geopolitical risks as a bigger long-term threat to the euro than the dollar despite near-term USD weakness.

Summary:

The dollar weakened as Greenland tensions and tariff threats escalated.

Barclays warns euro faces greater risk in a severe US–EU fallout.

NATO cohesion and European defence spending are key concerns.

Export-heavy economies like Germany are seen as most exposed.

Analysts expect limited US asset divestment even in worst case.

The US dollar weakened on Tuesday as markets reacted to an escalation in geopolitical tensions linked to President Donald Trump’s renewed push to assert control over Greenland, including threats to impose tariffs on European countries opposing the move.

While the greenback softened on the day, some strategists argue the longer-term risks from a deterioration in US–Europe relations may fall more heavily on the euro. Analysts at Barclays said that in an extreme scenario, the Greenland dispute could become a far greater problem for Europe and the single currency than for the United States.

Barclays noted that the situation has sharpened investor focus on strains within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, raising tail risks around alliance cohesion. European governments, already under pressure to lift defence spending following Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, have this month deployed troops to Greenland and now face the prospect of trade retaliation from Washington. In a worst-case outcome, Barclays warned that relations between the US and its NATO partners could deteriorate to the point where Washington effectively disengages from the alliance.

Other analysts echoed the view that a tougher trade environment would be more damaging for Europe than the US. Export-heavy economies such as Germany, the region’s largest, are seen as particularly exposed, with tariffs likely to hurt European corporates and growth prospects more than their US counterparts. That dynamic, strategists argue, would ultimately pressure the euro more than the dollar.

Market moves on Tuesday reflected near-term risk aversion. The ICE US Dollar Index fell around 0.8%, extending its decline over the past year to nearly 10%, while US equities and bonds also sold off sharply.

Barclays cautioned against over-interpreting these initial reactions, arguing that knee-jerk market moves often differ from longer-term outcomes. Its base case remains that the US and Europe eventually find a compromise allowing Washington to meet its security objectives in Greenland without a full rupture in relations.

Even in a more adverse scenario, the bank does not expect a wholesale exit from US assets. Instead, any dollar weakness would likely reflect low hedging ratios among foreign investors rather than a mass divestment. Barclays added that Europe’s fiscal constraints mean the bar for policy-driven euro support remains high unless there is coordinated joint issuance to fund common defence capabilities.

title: GSA officially appoints Michael Lynch as deputy administrator - FedScoop
description:
The General Services Administration officially appointed business executive Michael Lynch as the agency’s next deputy administrator after previously serving in a similar role.
Lynch served as a senior advisor under former acting GSA Administrator Stephen Ehikian during the first two months of the Trump administration before Ehikian “delegated the responsibilities” of deputy administrator to Lynch last March, per the press release.
Advertisement Prior to his time at GSA, Lynch served as the chief executive officer at Zedsen, a U.K.-based medical technology company using artificial intelligence in early-stage cancer detection.
He held other leadership roles at pharma giant Eli Lilly, Elon Musk’s SpaceX and other technology companies, the GSA said.
Forst, who was sworn in as administrator last month, said he has “full confidence” in Lynch’s ability to do the role.
text:
The General Services Administration officially appointed business executive Michael Lynch as the agency’s next deputy administrator after previously serving in a similar role.

GSA Administrator Ed Forst announced the appointment in a press release Tuesday, stating Lynch “demonstrated exceptional business acumen, strong leadership, and a clear track record of results.”

“In addition to serving as the agency’s chief operating officer, Mike will lead the development and execution of GSA’s performance culture, oversee the delivery of our automation initiatives, and champion the agencywide artificial intelligence strategy,” Forst added.

Lynch served as a senior advisor under former acting GSA Administrator Stephen Ehikian during the first two months of the Trump administration before Ehikian “delegated the responsibilities” of deputy administrator to Lynch last March, per the press release. In July, he returned to the role as a senior adviser.

Advertisement

Prior to his time at GSA, Lynch served as the chief executive officer at Zedsen, a U.K.-based medical technology company using artificial intelligence in early-stage cancer detection. He held other leadership roles at pharma giant Eli Lilly, Elon Musk’s SpaceX and other technology companies, the GSA said. He received a bachelor’s degree from Wabash College and graduate degrees from Indiana University and the London School of Economics.

Forst, who was sworn in as administrator last month, said he has “full confidence” in Lynch’s ability to do the role.

name: Kraft Heinz
title: Kraft Heinz Company (KHC) Registers Potential Resale of Shares - GuruFocus
description:
The Kraft Heinz Company (KHC, Financial) has recently filed a prospectus supplement with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on January 20, 2026.
The purpose of this filing is to register the potential resale of up to 325,442,152 shares of Kraft Heinz's common stock, each with a par value of $0.01.
Should any shares be sold, Kraft Heinz will not receive any proceeds from these transactions.
This prospectus supplement was filed under Kraft Heinz's automatic "shelf" Registration Statement on Form S-3ASR, which was previously submitted to the SEC on February 13, 2025.
For investors, this filing highlights the potential for significant share movements in the market, although it does not directly impact Kraft Heinz's financials or operations.
text:
The Kraft Heinz Company (KHC, Financial) has recently filed a prospectus supplement with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on January 20, 2026. This filing is part of an Amended and Restated Registration Rights Agreement, originally dated July 2, 2015, involving the company, 3G Global Food Holdings LP, and Berkshire Hathaway Inc., referred to as the Selling Stockholder.

The purpose of this filing is to register the potential resale of up to 325,442,152 shares of Kraft Heinz's common stock, each with a par value of $0.01. It is important to note that this filing does not constitute an actual sale of securities by the Selling Stockholder, nor does it guarantee that any shares will be sold. Should any shares be sold, Kraft Heinz will not receive any proceeds from these transactions.

This prospectus supplement was filed under Kraft Heinz's automatic "shelf" Registration Statement on Form S-3ASR, which was previously submitted to the SEC on February 13, 2025. The company has also provided a legal opinion regarding the validity of the shares covered by this supplement, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.

For investors, this filing highlights the potential for significant share movements in the market, although it does not directly impact Kraft Heinz's financials or operations. As always, investors should consider this information as part of their broader investment strategy.

name: Kraft Heinz
title: Kraft Heinz (KHC) Registers Shares for Potential Resale - GuruFocus
description:
Key Takeaways: Kraft Heinz (KHC, Financial) has initiated the registration for the potential resale of over 325 million shares, aligning with a longstanding agreement involving major stakeholders.
Despite recent challenges, Kraft Heinz maintains a robust market position with a market capitalization of approximately $28.12 billion.
Kraft Heinz (KHC) has announced in a recent regulatory filing that it has taken steps to register the possible resale of up to 325,442,152 shares of its common stock.
This agreement involves The Kraft Heinz Company, 3G Global Food Holdings LP, and Berkshire Hathaway.
The Kraft Heinz Company, formed through the merger of Kraft and Heinz in July 2015, stands as one of North America's largest food and beverage manufacturers.
text:
Key Takeaways:

Kraft Heinz (KHC, Financial) has initiated the registration for the potential resale of over 325 million shares, aligning with a longstanding agreement involving major stakeholders.

The company operates as a leading entity in the Consumer Defensive sector, with a significant presence in the global food and beverage market.

Despite recent challenges, Kraft Heinz maintains a robust market position with a market capitalization of approximately $28.12 billion.

Kraft Heinz (KHC) has announced in a recent regulatory filing that it has taken steps to register the possible resale of up to 325,442,152 shares of its common stock. This action is in accordance with the terms outlined in the Amended and Restated Registration Rights Agreement, which dates back to July 2, 2015. This agreement involves The Kraft Heinz Company, 3G Global Food Holdings LP, and Berkshire Hathaway. The company submitted a prospectus supplement to the Securities and Exchange Commission on January 20, 2026, to facilitate this registration exclusively for the Selling Stockholder. This move potentially positions these shares for resale in the open market.

The Kraft Heinz Company, formed through the merger of Kraft and Heinz in July 2015, stands as one of North America's largest food and beverage manufacturers. The company is strategically positioned in the Consumer Defensive sector, specifically within the Consumer Packaged Goods industry. Its extensive portfolio includes well-known brands such as Oscar Mayer, Velveeta, and Philadelphia. With a market capitalization of approximately $28.12 billion, Kraft Heinz operates a vast distribution network that spans over 190 countries and territories, contributing to nearly 25% of its consolidated sales base outside North America.

Financial Health Analysis

Kraft Heinz's financial performance reflects a complex landscape. The company's revenue stands at $25.16 billion, with a three-year revenue growth rate of 0%. Despite a gross margin of 33.71%, the company faces challenges with a net margin of -17.35% and an EPS of -3.73. The operating margin is relatively strong at 19.45%, but the EBITDA margin is negative at -18.65%.

On the balance sheet, Kraft Heinz exhibits a current ratio of 1.13 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51, indicating moderate leverage. The Altman Z-Score of 0.42 places the company in the distress zone, suggesting a potential risk of bankruptcy within the next two years. Insider activity reveals a trend of selling, with 250,000 shares sold in the past three months.

Valuation & Market Sentiment

In terms of valuation, Kraft Heinz's P/S ratio of 1.12 and P/B ratio of 0.68 are close to their historical lows, suggesting potential undervaluation. The forward P/E ratio is 9.47, indicating a cautious market outlook. Analyst recommendations average at 2.9, reflecting a hold sentiment. Technical indicators such as the RSI of 42.76 and moving averages suggest a neutral to slightly bearish trend.

Institutional ownership is robust at 83.5%, while insider ownership is relatively low at 0.96%. Recent insider activity has been predominantly selling, with no insider purchases in the past year.

Risk Assessment

text:

IBM Deepens Enterprise AI Push With Governance Focus And GRAMMY IQ

Simply Wall St

IBM launched IBM Enterprise Advantage, a new offering focused on enterprise AI adoption and governance.

The company announced a collaboration with e& to deploy one of the region's first enterprise-grade agentic AI governance solutions.

IBM also worked on GRAMMY IQ, applying its AI capabilities to fan engagement in entertainment.

International Business Machines (NYSE:IBM) is leaning further into enterprise AI with products and partnerships that aim to embed AI into core business and compliance workflows. The company’s recent moves come with the stock around $291.35 and a 1 year return of 33.3%, along with multi year gains of 129.7% over 3 years and 206.3% over 5 years.

For investors watching how large enterprises incorporate AI, these launches and collaborations highlight where IBM is focusing its efforts today. The breadth of use cases, from regulated corporate environments to fan engagement, may be useful context as you consider IBM’s role in AI driven business transformation.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for by adding it to your or . Alternatively, explore our to discover new perspectives on International Business Machines.

IBM Enterprise Advantage and the e& collaboration point in the same direction: IBM is leaning into agentic, governed AI as a core part of how large organizations run workflows, particularly in risk, compliance, and complex data environments. GRAMMY IQ then shows the same toolset applied to a consumer facing setting, which may help IBM showcase watsonx and its Granite models to a wide audience while still focusing on enterprise grade use cases behind the scenes.

Advertisement

How This Fits the International Business Machines Narrative

These announcements line up closely with existing narratives that emphasize IBM’s focus on hybrid cloud, AI and software execution, with consulting used as the delivery engine. Enterprise Advantage, in particular, speaks to the idea that IBM aims to be the partner that helps clients weave AI into day to day decision making, while the e& deployment and GRAMMY IQ give concrete proof points that may matter to investors who are tracking execution rather than just high level AI messaging.

Risks and Rewards Investors Are Weighing

Enterprise Advantage could support IBM’s push toward higher value consulting and software style engagements if clients adopt internal AI platforms at scale.

The e& deployment and GRAMMY IQ give IBM reference cases in both regulated and consumer settings, which may help win future AI and hybrid cloud work.

Analysts have highlighted execution risk around software and AI, and these offerings still need to translate into sustained revenue growth and margins to support more optimistic narratives.

IBM’s debt level remains a consideration for some investors when assessing how much flexibility the company has to keep investing in AI, quantum and acquisitions.

What To Watch Next

From here, it is useful to watch how many large clients adopt Enterprise Advantage, how broadly the e& governance solution is rolled out, and whether high profile projects like GRAMMY IQ lead to repeat work in other industries. name: AXA
title: SCOR and Axa launch Lloyd's consortium for ecological restoration risk - Beinsure
description:
The consortium aims to support financing for ecological restoration projects by reducing investment risk tied to implementation phases.
The initiative, branded Restore, is led by Scor Syndicate 2015 at Lloyd’s and managed by Scor Managing Agency.
Combined reach and balance sheet strength allow the structure to underwrite larger and more complex restoration projects across multiple regions.
That programme focuses on insurance solutions designed to support restoration and rehabilitation projects built around long-term environmental resilience.
The companies said the consortium is open to engagement with project developers, investors, and stakeholders active in ecological restoration.
text:
Scor, a French global reinsurance company headquartered, providing life, health, property, and casualty reinsurance services worldwide, and Axa, a French multinational insurance and financial services group, have launched a Lloyd’s consortium focused on ecological restoration, targeting a segment of environmental risk long left outside mainstream insurance coverage.

The consortium aims to support financing for ecological restoration projects by reducing investment risk tied to implementation phases.

By providing insurance protection, the partners intend to unlock capital for projects restoring ecosystems damaged or destroyed by prior activity.

The initiative, branded Restore, is led by Scor Syndicate 2015 at Lloyd’s and managed by Scor Managing Agency. Capacity support comes from Axa XL Syndicate 2003.

Combined reach and balance sheet strength allow the structure to underwrite larger and more complex restoration projects across multiple regions.

Scor and Axa said the consortium addresses a gap in the insurance market where projects aimed at ecosystem recovery struggle to secure protection during early and execution-heavy stages.

Restore underwrites the phase where conditions for ecological recovery are established, a point where uncertainty often deters investors.

The launch builds on Scor’s Nature Restoration and Conservation initiative introduced in May 2024. That programme focuses on insurance solutions designed to support restoration and rehabilitation projects built around long-term environmental resilience.

Jean-Paul Conoscente said the Restore structure increases the probability of project completion by improving confidence for developers and financiers.

Partnering with Axa, allows Scor to expand capacity and address environmental challenges at greater scale.

The companies said the consortium is open to engagement with project developers, investors, and stakeholders active in ecological restoration.

The aim is to build a pipeline of insurable projects where risk transfer helps convert environmental ambition into deployable capital.
