name: Eli Lilly
title: Is Novo Nordisk's Oral Wegovy Driving Strong Early US Demand Already? - Finviz
description:
The available prescription data reportedly reflects only retail channel activity and excludes volumes from Novo Nordisk’s direct-to-consumer online pharmacy, NovoCare.
As a result, the actual first-week sales performance could be meaningfully higher, underscoring the potential strength of the oral Wegovy launch trajectory.
It has priced oral Wegovy at $149 per month (without insurance).
Against this backdrop, Novo Nordisk’s launch of oral Wegovy gives it a first-mover advantage in the oral GLP-1 segment, positioning the company to regain market share from Lilly and drive incremental revenues.
During the same time frame, Novo Nordisk’s 2026 earnings estimates have declined from $3.65 to $3.52.
text:
Shares of Novo Nordisk NVO rose 9.1% on Friday after the company reportedly recorded strong early prescription trends just one week following the early-January U.S. launch of the oral version of its blockbuster GLP-1 therapy, Wegovy (semaglutide). The pill, approved in late December for obesity and cardiovascular risk reduction, is reportedly seeing robust initial demand, signaling an encouraging early uptake in the U.S. market.

The available prescription data reportedly reflects only retail channel activity and excludes volumes from Novo Nordisk’s direct-to-consumer online pharmacy, NovoCare. As a result, the actual first-week sales performance could be meaningfully higher, underscoring the potential strength of the oral Wegovy launch trajectory.

Please note that the Wegovy pill is the first oral GLP-1 drug to be approved in the United States, ushering in a new era of obesity treatment. The pill includes the same active ingredient — semaglutide — contained in NVO’s Wegovy and Ozempic injections (for type II diabetes). It has priced oral Wegovy at $149 per month (without insurance).

Eli Lilly LLY is Novo Nordisk’s arch-rival in the obesity space, which markets its tirzepatide (GLP-1) injections as Mounjaro (for type II diabetes) and Zepbound (for obesity). LLY has also filed a regulatory application seeking FDA approval for its oral GLP-1 drug, called orforglipron, for obesity. However, last week, the FDA reportedly delayed its decision on orforglipron to April 10 from the prior expectation of late March.

Daily oral obesity pills are expected to emerge as a more convenient and potentially lower-cost alternative to once-weekly injectables, such as Lilly’s Zepbound and Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy, lowering treatment burden and expanding patient adoption. With scalable manufacturing and broader appeal, Goldman Sachs estimates oral GLP-1 pills could generate about $22 billion in sales by 2030, or roughly 25% of a projected $95 billion global obesity drug market. Against this backdrop, Novo Nordisk’s launch of oral Wegovy gives it a first-mover advantage in the oral GLP-1 segment, positioning the company to regain market share from Lilly and drive incremental revenues. While analysts had expected Eli Lilly to close the gap quickly following a potential FDA approval of orforglipron in 2026, the latest delay puts LLY a step behind in the obesity pill race and gives Novo Nordisk additional time to strengthen its foothold in the oral obesity market.

Additionally, the regulatory body in the United Kingdom announced on Friday the approval of a 7.2 mg dose of Wegovy injection, which Novo Nordisk claims provides an option for “greater weight loss potential” than what is being offered by the available doses. This also likely contributed to the stock price gain as the improved efficacy profile could prompt physicians and patients to reconsider treatment choices, potentially shifting demand away from Lilly’s Zepbound toward the higher-dose Wegovy. Similar filings are also currently being reviewed in the United States and the EU. Favorable outcomes could improve NVO’s growth trajectory in the injectable treatment franchise.

Competition Heating Up in the Obesity Space

Eli Lilly is Novo Nordisk’s fierce competitor in the obesity space. Like NVO, Lilly is investing broadly in obesity and has several new molecules currently in clinical development with a range of oral and injectable medications with different mechanisms of action. Apart from orforglipron, LLY’s late-stage pipeline includes retatrutide, a GGG triagonist, as well as mid-stage candidates, including bimagrumab, eloralintide and mazdutide.

The obesity space has garnered much of the spotlight over the past year due to the sizeable and still underpenetrated market opportunity. Smaller biotech firms, like Viking Therapeutics VKTX, are also advancing GLP-1–based therapies to challenge the incumbents. Viking Therapeutics is developing its dual GIP/GLP-1 RA, VK2735, both as oral and subcutaneous formulations for the treatment of obesity. Last year, VKTX started two late-stage studies evaluating the subcutaneous formulation of VK2735. While one of these studies completed enrolment in November 2025 at a rapid pace, Viking Therapeutics expects to complete enrolment in the other study by the end of this quarter.

NVO Stock’s Price, Valuation & Estimates

In the past six months, Novo Nordisk shares have lost 4% against the industry’s 23.6% growth. The company has also underperformed the sector and the S&P 500 during the same time frame, as seen in the chart below.

NVO Stock Underperforms the Industry, Sector & the S&P 500

Image Source: Zacks Investment Research

Novo Nordisk is trading at a discount to the industry, as seen in the chart below. Going by the price/earnings ratio, the company’s shares currently trade at 17.67 forward earnings, which is marginally lower than 17.73 for the industry. The stock is trading much below its five-year mean of 29.25.

NVO Stock Valuation

Image Source: Zacks Investment Research

Earnings estimates for 2025 have remained constant at $3.58 per share over the past 60 days. During the same time frame, Novo Nordisk’s 2026 earnings estimates have declined from $3.65 to $3.52.

NVO Estimate Movement

Image Source: Zacks Investment Research

Novo Nordisk currently carries a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).

You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.

name: IBM
title: e& Partners with IBM to Deploy Enterprise-Grade Agentic AI for Governance and Compliance
description:
Global technology group e& has announced a strategic collaboration with IBM to advance enterprise-grade agentic AI, starting with policy, risk, and compliance processes.
A joint proof of concept by IBM, GBM (Gulf Business Machines), and e& demonstrated that agentic AI can operate at enterprise scale under real-world conditions.
The deployment enables trusted, explainable, and governed AI capable of streamlining compliance tasks, reducing response times, and providing 24/7 self-service access.
By embedding agentic AI into governance, risk, and compliance workflows, e& establishes a scalable foundation for enterprise AI adoption while maintaining regulatory and operational controls.
This collaboration showcases one of the region’s early enterprise-grade agentic AI implementations, integrating AI reasoning and task orchestration into business-critical systems.
text:
Global technology group e& has announced a strategic collaboration with IBM to advance enterprise-grade agentic AI, starting with policy, risk, and compliance processes. Unveiled at the World Economic Forum in Davos, the initiative represents a shift beyond traditional NLP-based chatbots toward AI that can reason, act, and integrate directly into core enterprise systems.

The solution, built on IBM watsonx Orchestrate and integrated with IBM OpenPages, leverages over 500 tools and domain-specific AI agents to help employees and auditors quickly access, interpret, and act on legal, regulatory, and compliance information. A joint proof of concept by IBM, GBM (Gulf Business Machines), and e& demonstrated that agentic AI can operate at enterprise scale under real-world conditions.

The deployment enables trusted, explainable, and governed AI capable of streamlining compliance tasks, reducing response times, and providing 24/7 self-service access. By embedding agentic AI into governance, risk, and compliance workflows, e& establishes a scalable foundation for enterprise AI adoption while maintaining regulatory and operational controls.

This collaboration showcases one of the region’s early enterprise-grade agentic AI implementations, integrating AI reasoning and task orchestration into business-critical systems. It also highlights IBM’s hybrid model gateway approach, allowing large language models to run across customer-managed infrastructure under strict governance.

The initiative aligns with e&’s broader goal of embedding AI intelligence into core operations, ensuring faster decisions, consistent policy interpretation, and responsible, human-led innovation.

name: HP Inc
title: HP unifies OMEN, HyperX as it debuts AI-driven gaming gear - Businessday NG
description:
HP Inc. is folding its OMEN gaming lineup into HyperX, betting that a single master brand can sharpen its push into high-end PCs, displays and peripherals as competition intensifies for gamers’ spending.
HyperX will now serve as HP’s end-to-end gaming brand, spanning laptops, monitors, controllers and software, the company said.
The company also expanded its display portfolio with the HyperX OMEN OLED 34, a 34-inch ultrawide monitor built on next-generation V-stripe QD-OLED panel technology.
On the peripherals side, HP introduced the HyperX Clutch Tachi, its first Xbox-licensed arcade-style controller.
HP also previewed a more experimental product: an in-development HyperX gaming headset created with neurotechnology startup Neurable.
text:
HP Inc. is folding its OMEN gaming lineup into HyperX, betting that a single master brand can sharpen its push into high-end PCs, displays and peripherals as competition intensifies for gamers’ spending.

The company unveiled the strategy at the CES trade show in Las Vegas, alongside a slate of new products that lean heavily on artificial intelligence, faster displays and custom hardware.

HyperX will now serve as HP’s end-to-end gaming brand, spanning laptops, monitors, controllers and software, the company said.

The move brings together two names HP has spent years building — OMEN for gaming PCs and displays, and HyperX for accessories — under one banner as rivals such as Lenovo Group Ltd.’s Legion and Dell Technologies Inc.’s Alienware expand tightly integrated ecosystems.

“Gamers deserve a seamless experience that matches their passion, from the systems that power their worlds to the gear that connects them,” Josephine Tan, senior vice president and division president of personal systems gaming solutions at HP, said in a statement.

Read also: HP unveils AI-powered OmniBook lineup as PC makers chase post-pandemic demand

At the center of HP’s CES lineup is the HyperX OMEN MAX 16, a new flagship gaming laptop that the company says is its most powerful to date. The machine is designed to deliver up to 300 watts of total platform power, a jump from the previous generation, using Intel’s Core Ultra 200HX processors or next-generation AMD Ryzen AI chips paired with Nvidia’s GeForce RTX 5090 laptop GPU.

HP said the device relies on a fully internal cooling system, including a redesigned OMEN Tempest Cooling Pro architecture with a third fan, to sustain performance during extended gaming sessions.

The laptop also features a high-polling-rate keyboard aimed at reducing input lag and an OLED display option with a 240-hertz refresh rate.

Artificial intelligence plays a bigger role this generation. HP is positioning its OMEN AI software as a one-click optimisation tool that automatically tunes operating system, hardware and in-game settings to boost frame rates, removing the need for manual configuration.

The company also expanded its display portfolio with the HyperX OMEN OLED 34, a 34-inch ultrawide monitor built on next-generation V-stripe QD-OLED panel technology.

The monitor offers a 360-hertz refresh rate and near-instant response times, targeting competitive players as well as creators who need accurate color reproduction. Features such as USB-C power delivery and a built-in KVM switch are aimed at users juggling multiple devices.

On the peripherals side, HP introduced the HyperX Clutch Tachi, its first Xbox-licensed arcade-style controller. The leverless controller uses magnetic switches and supports extensive customization through HP’s NGENUITY software, including user-designed modifications produced via 3D printing.

HP also previewed a more experimental product: an in-development HyperX gaming headset created with neurotechnology startup Neurable.

The headset uses electroencephalography sensors and AI to interpret brain activity in real time, with the goal of helping players improve focus and accuracy — an early signal of how HP sees neuroscience intersecting with gaming.

The new products are expected to be available in the spring through HP’s website, with pricing to be announced closer to launch.

For HP, which has been working to revive demand in a sluggish PC market, gaming remains one of the more resilient segments.

name: Societe Generale
title: Georgia to print for first time since 2021 despite geopolitical tensions - Global Capital
description:
Illustrations A car manufacturer wants to promote its electric vehicles to environmentally conscious users living in the city after office hours.
The number of times that the ad has been presented to you is detected and limited, to avoid presenting it too often.
This is then used to build or improve a profile about you (that might include possible interests and personal aspects).
Your profile can be used (also later) to present advertising that appears more relevant based on your possible interests by this and other entities.
Number of Vendors seeking consent: 0
text:
Cookies, device or similar online identifiers (e.g. login-based identifiers, randomly assigned identifiers, network based identifiers) together with other information (e.g. browser type and information, language, screen size, supported technologies etc.) can be stored or read on your device to recognise it each time it connects to an app or to a website, for one or several of the purposes presented here.

Illustrations

Most purposes explained in this notice rely on the storage or accessing of information from your device when you use an app or visit a website. For example, a vendor or publisher might need to store a cookie on your device during your first visit on a website, to be able to recognise your device during your next visits (by accessing this cookie each time).

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 3

Advertising presented to you on this service can be based on limited data, such as the website or app you are using, your non-precise location, your device type or which content you are (or have been) interacting with (for example, to limit the number of times an ad is presented to you).

Illustrations

A car manufacturer wants to promote its electric vehicles to environmentally conscious users living in the city after office hours. The advertising is presented on a page with related content (such as an article on climate change actions) after 6:30 p.m. to users whose non-precise location suggests that they are in an urban zone.

A large producer of watercolour paints wants to carry out an online advertising campaign for its latest watercolour range, diversifying its audience to reach as many amateur and professional artists as possible and avoiding showing the ad next to mismatched content (for instance, articles about how to paint your house). The number of times that the ad has been presented to you is detected and limited, to avoid presenting it too often.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 3

Information about your activity on this service (such as forms you submit, content you look at) can be stored and combined with other information about you (for example, information from your previous activity on this service and other websites or apps) or similar users. This is then used to build or improve a profile about you (that might include possible interests and personal aspects). Your profile can be used (also later) to present advertising that appears more relevant based on your possible interests by this and other entities.

Illustrations

If you read several articles about the best bike accessories to buy, this information could be used to create a profile about your interest in bike accessories. Such a profile may be used or improved later on, on the same or a different website or app to present you with advertising for a particular bike accessory brand. If you also look at a configurator for a vehicle on a luxury car manufacturer website, this information could be combined with your interest in bikes to refine your profile and make an assumption that you are interested in luxury cycling gear.

An apparel company wishes to promote its new line of high-end baby clothes. It gets in touch with an agency that has a network of clients with high income customers (such as high-end supermarkets) and asks the agency to create profiles of young parents or couples who can be assumed to be wealthy and to have a new child, so that these can later be used to present advertising within partner apps based on those profiles.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 3

Advertising presented to you on this service can be based on your advertising profiles, which can reflect your activity on this service or other websites or apps (like the forms you submit, content you look at), possible interests and personal aspects.

Illustrations

An online retailer wants to advertise a limited sale on running shoes. It wants to target advertising to users who previously looked at running shoes on its mobile app. Tracking technologies might be used to recognise that you have previously used the mobile app to consult running shoes, in order to present you with the corresponding advertisement on the app.

A profile created for personalised advertising in relation to a person having searched for bike accessories on a website can be used to present the relevant advertisement for bike accessories on a mobile app of another organisation.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 3

Information about your activity on this service (for instance, forms you submit, non-advertising content you look at) can be stored and combined with other information about you (such as your previous activity on this service or other websites or apps) or similar users. This is then used to build or improve a profile about you (which might for example include possible interests and personal aspects). Your profile can be used (also later) to present content that appears more relevant based on your possible interests, such as by adapting the order in which content is shown to you, so that it is even easier for you to find content that matches your interests.

Illustrations

You read several articles on how to build a treehouse on a social media platform. This information might be added to a profile to mark your interest in content related to outdoors as well as do-it-yourself guides (with the objective of allowing the personalisation of content, so that for example you are presented with more blog posts and articles on treehouses and wood cabins in the future).

You have viewed three videos on space exploration across different TV apps. An unrelated news platform with which you have had no contact builds a profile based on that viewing behaviour, marking space exploration as a topic of possible interest for other videos.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 0

Content presented to you on this service can be based on your content personalisation profiles, which can reflect your activity on this or other services (for instance, the forms you submit, content you look at), possible interests and personal aspects. This can for example be used to adapt the order in which content is shown to you, so that it is even easier for you to find (non-advertising) content that matches your interests.

Illustrations

You read articles on vegetarian food on a social media platform and then use the cooking app of an unrelated company. The profile built about you on the social media platform will be used to present you vegetarian recipes on the welcome screen of the cooking app.

You have viewed three videos about rowing across different websites. An unrelated video sharing platform will recommend five other videos on rowing that may be of interest to you when you use your TV app, based on a profile built about you when you visited those different websites to watch online videos.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 0

Information regarding which advertising is presented to you and how you interact with it can be used to determine how well an advert has worked for you or other users and whether the goals of the advertising were reached. For instance, whether you saw an ad, whether you clicked on it, whether it led you to buy a product or visit a website, etc. This is very helpful to understand the relevance of advertising campaigns.

Illustrations

You have clicked on an advertisement about a “black Friday” discount by an online shop on the website of a publisher and purchased a product. Your click will be linked to this purchase. Your interaction and that of other users will be measured to know how many clicks on the ad led to a purchase.

You are one of very few to have clicked on an advertisement about an “international appreciation day” discount by an online gift shop within the app of a publisher. The publisher wants to have reports to understand how often a specific ad placement within the app, and notably the “international appreciation day” ad, has been viewed or clicked by you and other users, in order to help the publisher and its partners (such as agencies) optimise ad placements.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 3

Information regarding which content is presented to you and how you interact with it can be used to determine whether the (non-advertising) content e.g. reached its intended audience and matched your interests. For instance, whether you read an article, watch a video, listen to a podcast or look at a product description, how long you spent on this service and the web pages you visit etc. This is very helpful to understand the relevance of (non-advertising) content that is shown to you.

Illustrations

You have read a blog post about hiking on a mobile app of a publisher and followed a link to a recommended and related post. Your interactions will be recorded as showing that the initial hiking post was useful to you and that it was successful in interesting you in the related post. This will be measured to know whether to produce more posts on hiking in the future and where to place them on the home screen of the mobile app.

You were presented a video on fashion trends, but you and several other users stopped watching after 30 seconds. This information is then used to evaluate the right length of future videos on fashion trends.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 0

Reports can be generated based on the combination of data sets (like user profiles, statistics, market research, analytics data) regarding your interactions and those of other users with advertising or (non-advertising) content to identify common characteristics (for instance, to determine which target audiences are more receptive to an ad campaign or to certain contents).

Illustrations

The owner of an online bookstore wants commercial reporting showing the proportion of visitors who consulted and left its site without buying, or consulted and bought the last celebrity autobiography of the month, as well as the average age and the male/female distribution of each category. Data relating to your navigation on its site and to your personal characteristics is then used and combined with other such data to produce these statistics.

An advertiser wants to better understand the type of audience interacting with its adverts. It calls upon a research institute to compare the characteristics of users who interacted with the ad with typical attributes of users of similar platforms, across different devices. This comparison reveals to the advertiser that its ad audience is mainly accessing the adverts through mobile devices and is likely in the 45-60 age range.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 3

Information about your activity on this service, such as your interaction with ads or content, can be very helpful to improve products and services and to build new products and services based on user interactions, the type of audience, etc. This specific purpose does not include the development or improvement of user profiles and identifiers.

Illustrations

A technology platform working with a social media provider notices a growth in mobile app users, and sees based on their profiles that many of them are connecting through mobile connections. It uses a new technology to deliver ads that are formatted for mobile devices and that are low-bandwidth, to improve their performance.

An advertiser is looking for a way to display ads on a new type of consumer device. It collects information regarding the way users interact with this new kind of device to determine whether it can build a new mechanism for displaying advertising on this type of device.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 3

Content presented to you on this service can be based on limited data, such as the website or app you are using, your non-precise location, your device type, or which content you are (or have been) interacting with (for example, to limit the number of times a video or an article is presented to you).

Illustrations

A travel magazine has published an article on its website about the new online courses proposed by a language school, to improve travelling experiences abroad. The school’s blog posts are inserted directly at the bottom of the page, and selected on the basis of your non-precise location (for instance, blog posts explaining the course curriculum for different languages than the language of the country you are situated in).

A sports news mobile app has started a new section of articles covering the most recent football games. Each article includes videos hosted by a separate streaming platform showcasing the highlights of each match. If you fast-forward a video, this information may be used to select a shorter video to play next.

Number of Vendors seeking consent or relying on legitimate interest: 0

Your data can be used to monitor for and prevent unusual and possibly fraudulent activity (for example, regarding advertising, ad clicks by bots), and ensure systems and processes work properly and securely. It can also be used to correct any problems you, the publisher or the advertiser may encounter in the delivery of content and ads and in your interaction with them.

Illustrations

An advertising intermediary delivers ads from various advertisers to its network of partnering websites. It notices a large increase in clicks on ads relating to one advertiser, and uses data regarding the source of the clicks to determine that 80% of the clicks come from bots rather than humans.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 3

The choices you make regarding the purposes and entities listed in this notice are saved and made available to those entities in the form of digital signals (such as a string of characters). This is necessary in order to enable both this service and those entities to respect such choices.

Illustrations

When you visit a website and are offered a choice between consenting to the use of profiles for personalised advertising or not consenting, the choice you make is saved and made available to advertising providers, so that advertising presented to you respects that choice.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 2

Information about your activity on this service may be matched and combined with other information relating to you and originating from various sources (for instance your activity on a separate online service, your use of a loyalty card in-store, or your answers to a survey), in support of the purposes explained in this notice.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 3

In support of the purposes explained in this notice, your device might be considered as likely linked to other devices that belong to you or your household (for instance because you are logged in to the same service on both your phone and your computer, or because you may use the same Internet connection on both devices).

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 2

Your device might be distinguished from other devices based on information it automatically sends when accessing the Internet (for instance, the IP address of your Internet connection or the type of browser you are using) in support of the purposes exposed in this notice.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 1

With your acceptance, certain characteristics specific to your device might be requested and used to distinguish it from other devices (such as the installed fonts or plugins, the resolution of your screen) in support of the purposes explained in this notice.

Number of Vendors seeking consent: 0

name: J&J
title: The New Era of Johnson & Johnson: A 2026 Deep-Dive Research Feature
description:
As of January 19, 2026, Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: JNJ) stands as a radically different enterprise than the one most investors recognized just three years ago.
Business Model Johnson & Johnson operates through two primary segments, having streamlined its operations to maximize agility and returns: Innovative Medicine (formerly Pharmaceuticals): This segment generates approximately 65% of total revenue.
Financial Performance Johnson & Johnson enters 2026 with a formidable balance sheet.
Products, Services, and Innovations Innovation is the lifeblood of the 2026 JNJ investment thesis.
Conclusion As we move through 2026, Johnson & Johnson is a company in the final stages of a profound metamorphosis.
text:
As of January 19, 2026, Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: JNJ) stands as a radically different enterprise than the one most investors recognized just three years ago. Following the successful spin-off of its consumer health division, Kenvue, JNJ has fully transitioned into a high-growth, pure-play healthcare powerhouse focused exclusively on Innovative Medicine and Medical Technology (MedTech).

Today, the company is in the spotlight not for Band-Aids or Tylenol, but for its aggressive pivot into high-complexity surgical robotics, life-saving cardiovascular devices, and a pharmaceutical pipeline that is successfully navigating a historic "patent cliff." With its recent acquisitions of Abiomed and Shockwave Medical now fully integrated, and the highly anticipated Ottava robotic system nearing the final stages of regulatory approval, JNJ is positioned to define the next decade of healthcare delivery. This article explores how JNJ is balancing legacy litigation risks with a bold 2026 growth strategy.

Historical Background

Founded in 1886 by three brothers in New Brunswick, New Jersey, Johnson & Johnson’s early identity was forged in the development of sterile surgical dressings and the first commercial first-aid kits. For over a century, the company functioned as a decentralized conglomerate, often referred to as a "broad-based" healthcare giant.

The 20th century saw JNJ expand into pharmaceuticals (founding Janssen Pharmaceutica) and medical devices (acquiring DePuy and Ethicon). However, the most significant transformation in the company’s history occurred in August 2023, when JNJ finalized the separation of its Consumer Health business. This maneuver allowed the "New J&J" to shed its slower-growing retail segments to focus capital and R&D on the high-margin, high-innovation sectors of biologics and specialized medical hardware. This evolution marks a return to the company’s high-science roots while maintaining the operational discipline that has made it one of the few AAA-rated corporations in the world.

Business Model

Johnson & Johnson operates through two primary segments, having streamlined its operations to maximize agility and returns:

Innovative Medicine (formerly Pharmaceuticals): This segment generates approximately 65% of total revenue. It focuses on six core therapeutic areas: Oncology, Immunology, Neuroscience, Cardiovascular/Metabolism, Pulmonary Hypertension, and Infectious Diseases. The model relies on "blockbuster" biologics and a robust R&D engine to replace revenues lost to patent expirations.

Medical Technology (MedTech): Accounting for the remaining 35% of revenue, this segment is a global leader in Surgery, Orthopaedics, Vision, and Interventional Solutions. Following a string of multi-billion dollar acquisitions, MedTech is now heavily weighted toward cardiovascular care and digital/robotic surgery, which offer higher growth rates and stickier hospital relationships than traditional mechanical instruments.

The company's customer base is global, selling primarily to hospitals, healthcare providers, and wholesalers, with a growing emphasis on value-based care partnerships where JNJ products are integrated into hospital workflows to improve patient outcomes.

Stock Performance Overview

Over the past decade, JNJ has traditionally been viewed as a "defensive" stock—a core holding for income-seeking investors due to its status as a Dividend King. However, its price action has been a tale of two eras:

10-Year Horizon: JNJ has delivered steady, albeit market-trailing, returns as it navigated the litigation-heavy 2010s. The stock has been a reliable source of capital preservation, with dividends reinvested significantly boosting total returns.

5-Year Horizon: Performance was marked by the volatility of the COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent restructuring. The 2023 Kenvue split provided a "special dividend" in the form of shares, but the core JNJ ticker saw sideways movement as the market weighed the talc litigation against the new growth profile.

1-Year Horizon (2025–2026): Over the last twelve months, JNJ has begun to outperform the broader healthcare sector (XLV). As of January 2026, the market has started to reward the company for its double-digit growth in oncology and the successful integration of Shockwave Medical.

Financial Performance

Johnson & Johnson enters 2026 with a formidable balance sheet. Preliminary 2025 results indicate a resilient fiscal year:

Revenue: 2025 revenue is projected at approximately $93.2 billion, a 5.5% increase year-over-year.

Earnings Per Share (EPS): Adjusted operational EPS for 2025 is estimated at $10.85, reflecting the company’s ability to manage costs despite the biosimilar competition for its top-selling drug, Stelara.

Margins and Cash Flow: Operating margins remain healthy at nearly 30%, supported by the higher-margin pharmaceutical mix. The company generates roughly $20 billion in annual free cash flow, which powers its aggressive M&A strategy and dividend increases.

Valuation: Trading at approximately 15.5x forward earnings, JNJ continues to trade at a discount compared to peers like Eli Lilly (NYSE: LLY) or Novo Nordisk (NYSE: NVO), largely due to the "litigation discount" applied by institutional investors regarding talc liabilities.

Leadership and Management

CEO Joaquin Duato, who took the helm in early 2022, has been the primary architect of the "New J&J." His leadership is characterized by a "MedTech-First" investment philosophy and a decisive move to modernize the company's pharmaceutical portfolio.

Under Duato, the management team has become more aggressive in capital allocation. The board of directors, known for its conservative governance, has supported Duato’s shift toward high-risk, high-reward acquisitions like Abiomed ($16.6B) and Shockwave Medical ($13.1B). This leadership team is currently focused on two critical execution targets for 2026: the successful FDA submission of the Ottava robotic system and the ongoing spinoff of the slower-growing DePuy Synthes orthopaedics business.

Products, Services, and Innovations

Innovation is the lifeblood of the 2026 JNJ investment thesis. The company currently boasts 11 "priority platforms" that each generate over $1 billion in annual sales.

Oncology Dominance: Darzalex (for multiple myeloma) has become the crown jewel of the portfolio, surpassing $3 billion in quarterly sales in 2025. Meanwhile, Carvykti, a CAR-T cell therapy, is seeing nearly 90% growth as manufacturing scales and it moves into earlier-line treatments.

Cardiovascular MedTech: The acquisition of Shockwave Medical has introduced Intravascular Lithotripsy (IVL) to the JNJ portfolio—a game-changing technology that uses sonic pressure waves to crack calcified plaque in heart arteries. This, alongside Abiomed’s Impella heart pumps, makes JNJ a leader in interventional cardiology.

Robotics (Ottava): In January 2026, JNJ submitted its Ottava robotic surgery system for FDA De Novo classification. Unlike existing systems, Ottava features six arms integrated into a standard operating table, promising to save space and increase surgical flexibility.

Competitive Landscape

JNJ competes in a bifurcated landscape:

In Pharma: It faces intense competition from Merck (NYSE: MRK) in oncology and AbbVie (NYSE: ABBV) in immunology. While JNJ lost exclusivity for Stelara in late 2024, its newer oral IL-23 peptide, Icotrokinra, is positioned to recapture market share in 2026.

In MedTech: Its primary rival in the robotic space is Intuitive Surgical (NASDAQ: ISRG). While Intuitive’s Da Vinci 5 remains the market leader, JNJ’s strategy is to leverage its deep relationships with hospitals (via its Ethicon surgical tools) to bundle the Ottava system, potentially disrupting Intuitive's dominance.

Industry and Market Trends

The healthcare sector in 2026 is being shaped by three macro drivers:

AI and Digital Surgery: JNJ is integrating AI into its Polyphonic digital ecosystem, which provides surgeons with real-time data and video analytics during procedures.

Consolidation of Care: Hospitals are increasingly looking for "single-source" partners. JNJ’s broad MedTech portfolio allows it to offer comprehensive solutions that smaller niche players cannot match.

The "Patent Cliff" Cycle: As large-cap pharma companies face losses of exclusivity, there is a sector-wide rush toward M&A. JNJ is a leader in this trend, having spent over $30 billion on acquisitions in the last three years.

Risks and Challenges

Despite its strengths, JNJ faces significant headwinds:

Talc Litigation: This remains the "elephant in the room." As of January 2026, over 67,000 cases remain in the federal Multi-District Litigation (MDL). Despite attempts to use the "Texas Two-Step" bankruptcy strategy, the courts have forced JNJ back into mediation. Recent multi-billion dollar verdicts in California and Maryland continue to worry shareholders.

Inflation Reduction Act (IRA): In 2026, the first wave of Medicare price negotiations takes effect. JNJ’s Stelara is among the impacted drugs, which may pressure margins even as biosimilar competition intensifies.

Execution Risk: The integration of Shockwave and the launch of Ottava are high-stakes maneuvers. Any regulatory delay in the Ottava approval could allow competitors to further entrench their market share.

Opportunities and Catalysts

Looking ahead at 2026, several catalysts could re-rate the stock:

2026 Earnings Guidance: During the January 2026 J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference, management targeted a 5% to 7% operational sales CAGR through 2030. If the company hits the high end of this range in its Q1 and Q2 reports, it could trigger a significant valuation multiple expansion.

DePuy Synthes Spinoff: The plan to spin off the orthopaedics business by late 2026 will further refine JNJ into a high-growth entity, potentially attracting a new class of "growth" investors.

Icotrokinra Launch: The expected 2026 launch of the first oral biologic-like treatment for psoriasis could be a multi-billion dollar catalyst for the Innovative Medicine segment.

Investor Sentiment and Analyst Coverage

Wall Street sentiment toward JNJ is currently "Cautiously Bullish."

Institutional Support: Large asset managers like Vanguard and BlackRock remain the largest holders, attracted by the 3% dividend yield and the AAA credit rating.

Analyst Views: Many analysts have moved JNJ to a "Buy" rating in late 2025, citing that the Stelara patent cliff is now "baked in" and that the MedTech growth is being undervalued.

Hedge Fund Interest: There has been a notable uptick in "event-driven" hedge fund interest, with some betting on a final global settlement of the talc litigation in 2026, which would remove the primary obstacle to the stock's appreciation.

Regulatory, Policy, and Geopolitical Factors

JNJ’s global footprint makes it sensitive to geopolitical shifts.

U.S. Policy: The 2026 implementation of the IRA is the most significant domestic policy shift. JNJ is actively lobbying for reforms while simultaneously pivoting its pipeline toward "small molecule" drugs that may be less impacted by certain IRA provisions.

China Market: JNJ continues to see China as a critical growth market for MedTech, though trade tensions and localized "buy Chinese" policies for medical devices present ongoing challenges for the Ethicon and DePuy units.

Conclusion

As we move through 2026, Johnson & Johnson is a company in the final stages of a profound metamorphosis. By divesting its consumer roots and doubling down on high-science pharma and interventional MedTech, it has positioned itself for a new era of growth.

Investors should watch two things closely in 2026: the regulatory progress of the Ottava robotic system and any definitive legal resolution to the talc litigation. If JNJ can clear its legal hurdles while executing its ambitious MedTech integration, it may finally break out of its defensive shell and reclaim its status as a premier growth-and-income engine in the healthcare sector. For the Finterra investor, JNJ represents a calculated bet on the future of medical innovation, underpinned by one of the strongest balance sheets in corporate history.

This content is intended for informational purposes only and is not financial advice.

name: Parker-Hannifin
title: HAECO Welcomes Haijun Jiang with Years of Experience in the Aerospace Industry as the ...
description:
Hong Kong Aircraft Engineering Company Limited (HAECO), a leading player in the aerospace industry, has announced the appointment of Haijun Jiang as the General Manager of HAECO Composite Services, with immediate effect.
Extensive Expertise in Aerospace Industry Jiang brings over 20 years of experience in the aerospace industry, including more than 15 years in various commercial and operational leadership roles.
HAECO Composite Services: A Key Player in Aircraft Maintenance HAECO Composite Services is widely recognized for its comprehensive aircraft maintenance solutions, particularly its advanced composite repair capabilities.
Located in Jinjiang, Fujian Province, HAECO Composite Services is strategically positioned to serve clients across the Asia Pacific region.
Conclusion HAECO’s appointment of Haijun Jiang as General Manager of HAECO Composite Services is a strategic move to further strengthen its position in the global aerospace industry.
text:
Hong Kong Aircraft Engineering Company Limited (HAECO), a leading player in the aerospace industry, has announced the appointment of Haijun Jiang as the General Manager of HAECO Composite Services, with immediate effect. In this crucial role, Jiang will oversee the company’s strategic direction and business growth. With his extensive experience in the aerospace sector, he is expected to drive operational performance and profitability while maintaining the highest standards of safety, quality and regulatory compliance. The appointment underscores HAECO’s commitment to strengthening its position in the global aircraft maintenance and engineering services market.

Extensive Expertise in Aerospace Industry

Jiang brings over 20 years of experience in the aerospace industry, including more than 15 years in various commercial and operational leadership roles. His career has been marked by full P&L responsibility, along with serving as a Part 145 Accountable Manager. Before joining HAECO, Jiang was the Regional Business Director at Parker Hannifin, where he played a key role in business development and joint venture initiatives across Mainland China. His previous experience also includes management positions at Honeywell and he began his career at Guangzhou Aircraft Maintenance Engineering.

Jiang’s career trajectory has positioned him as a respected leader in the aerospace sector and his knowledge of business development and operational management will be invaluable in leading HAECO Composite Services into its next phase of growth. His leadership will play a crucial role in enhancing HAECO’s market presence and continuing to provide top-tier aircraft maintenance solutions to its clients worldwide.

HAECO Composite Services: A Key Player in Aircraft Maintenance

HAECO Composite Services is widely recognized for its comprehensive aircraft maintenance solutions, particularly its advanced composite repair capabilities. The company specializes in end-to-end services for a range of aircraft components, including engine nacelles, flight control surfaces and radomes. Its repair services extend across multiple aircraft types, cementing its reputation as a trusted partner in the aerospace industry.

Located in Jinjiang, Fujian Province, HAECO Composite Services is strategically positioned to serve clients across the Asia Pacific region. The company is a key strategic partner for major aerospace manufacturers, including Airbus Avionics. Additionally, it holds the esteemed designation of an Authorized Component Repair Centre (Asia Pacific) for leading companies such as Bombardier Aerospace, Boeing Global Services and Safran Nacelles. This partnership enables HAECO to provide high-quality repair services that meet the rigorous standards set by global aerospace leaders.

Driving Innovation in Aircraft Maintenance

Under Jiang’s leadership, HAECO Composite Services is set to enhance its operational capabilities and expand its service offerings. With a focus on continuous improvement, HAECO aims to push the boundaries of innovation in the aircraft maintenance industry. The company’s reputation for excellence in composite repair, combined with its strong global partnerships, positions it as a leading force in the sector.

As the aerospace industry continues to evolve, HAECO remains committed to delivering cutting-edge solutions that meet the growing demands of its clients. Jiang’s appointment signifies a new chapter for HAECO Composite Services, one focused on innovation, growth and continued leadership in the aircraft maintenance field.

Conclusion

HAECO’s appointment of Haijun Jiang as General Manager of HAECO Composite Services is a strategic move to further strengthen its position in the global aerospace industry. With his extensive experience and proven track record in the sector, Jiang is poised to lead the company towards greater success. HAECO’s commitment to providing high-quality aircraft maintenance services, coupled with its strong partnerships with major aerospace manufacturers, ensures that it will continue to be a trusted leader in the industry.

name: Eli Lilly
title: Prediction: 2026 Will Be the Year of Eli Lilly | The Motley Fool
description:
Eli Lilly (LLY +0.52%) has behaved more like a tech stock in recent years than like a pharma stock.
Lilly sells tirzepatide, sold under the name Mounjaro for type 2 diabetes and Zepbound for weight loss.
In fact, my prediction is that 2026 will be the year of Eli Lilly.
Because the company may soon launch a key product: a weight loss pill.
Rival Novo recently won approval for its weight loss pill, but I'm confident Lilly's potential pill would win market share.
text:
Eli Lilly (LLY +0.52%) has behaved more like a tech stock in recent years than like a pharma stock. Tech players are known to soar in the double and triple digits when the environment and corporate news are supportive. Pharmaceutical companies generally take a slower but steady path, and this is due to the fact that patients always need their medicines -- this supports revenue stability over time.

So, why has Lilly become a growth stock? The company has established leadership in an area of high demand: the weight loss drug market. Lilly sells tirzepatide, sold under the name Mounjaro for type 2 diabetes and Zepbound for weight loss. Together, these drugs delivered more than $10 billion in revenue in the latest quarter and helped the company's overall revenue soar in the double digits.

I think this momentum is far from over. In fact, my prediction is that 2026 will be the year of Eli Lilly. And this is for one specific reason...

Lilly's blockbuster revenue

As mentioned, Lilly has generated blockbuster revenue thanks to its weight loss portfolio. Doctors have prescribed either of the injectable drugs for weight control, and demand has been high. It even resulted in drug shortages a couple of years ago until Lilly expanded its manufacturing capacity.

Demand continues to march on, and analysts predict that the obesity drug market will approach $100 billion by the end of this decade.

Right now, Lilly shares the market with Novo Nordisk, maker of Ozempic and Wegovy, but Lilly has advanced due to the efficacy of its drugs and its aggressive buildout of manufacturing infrastructure to meet demand.

NYSE : LLY

Eli Lilly

Today's Change

( 0.52 %) $ 5.32

A potential new launch

Why do I expect this year to be a big one for Lilly? Because the company may soon launch a key product: a weight loss pill. Lilly applied for the regulatory review of orforglipron late last year, and trial results have been solid. A pill could be a significant product for two reasons: It's more convenient for patients to take on the go and avoids a needle stick -- something many aren't too fond of. And for Lilly, a pill is cheaper and easier to manufacture than an injectable in pen format.

Rival Novo recently won approval for its weight loss pill, but I'm confident Lilly's potential pill would win market share. After taking Novo's Wegovy pill, patients must avoid food and drink for half an hour; Lilly's doesn't involve any dietary restrictions, making it extremely easy to fit into a daily routine.

name: HP Inc
title: Zacks Industry Outlook Highlights C.H. Robinson, J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Saia and ArcBest
description:
Notable players expected to withstand these challenges include J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Saia and ArcBest Corp. Industry Description The Zacks Transportation - Truck industry houses truck operators transporting freight to diverse customers, mainly across North America.
Prolonged Truck-Driver Shortage: The persistent driver crisis in the trucking industry is worsening supply-chain challenges across the United States.
Zacks Industry Rank Indicates Dull Prospects The Zacks Transportation - Truck industry is a 12-stock group.
The industry currently carries a Zacks Industry Rank #234, which places it in the bottom 2% of 243 Zacks industries.
The group’s Zacks Industry Rank, the average of the Zacks Rank of all member stocks, indicates murky near-term prospects.
text:
For Immediate Release

Chicago, IL – January 19, 2026 – Today, Zacks Equity Research discusses C.H. Robinson Worldwide CHRW, J.B. Hunt Transport Services JBHT, Saia SAIA and ArcBest Corp. ARCB.

Industry: Transportation - Trucking

Link: https://www.zacks.com/commentary/2818625/3-truck-stocks-positioned-to-navigate-industry-challenges

The Zacks Transportation-Truck industry continues to face supply-chain disruptions, a weak freight scenario and a difficult macroeconomic backdrop marked by geopolitical tensions, still-high inflation levels and a shortage of truck drivers. The freight downturn is hurting players in other corners of the broader Zacks Transportation sector as well. For example, C.H. Robinson Worldwide is also hurt by this prolonged freight recession.

Despite these headwinds and the resulting demand uncertainty, the truck industry has demonstrated resilience, particularly among companies that focus on growth strategies and operational efficiency. Notable players expected to withstand these challenges include J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Saia and ArcBest Corp.

Industry Description

The Zacks Transportation - Truck industry houses truck operators transporting freight to diverse customers, mainly across North America. These companies provide full-truckload or less-than-truckload (“LTL”) services over the short, medium or long haul. The range of trucking services these companies provide includes dry-van, dedicated, refrigerated, flatbed and expedited. Some companies have an extensive fleet of company-owned tractors and trucks, and independent contractor trucks.

Besides trucking, most entities offer logistics and intermodal services as well as value-added services like container drayage, truckload brokerage, supply-chain consulting and warehousing. A few also offer asset-light services to other third-party logistics companies in the transportation sector.

3 Trends Shaping the Future of the Trucking Industry

Prolonged Freight Downturn Remains Worrisome: Although economic activities picked up from the pandemic gloom, lingering supply-chain disruptions continue to dent stocks in the industry. Below-par freight rates are also hurting the industry’s prospects. Highlighting weak freight demand, the Cass Freight Shipments Index declined 7.6% year over year in November 2025. This measure has deteriorated year over year each of the past nine months, which confirms the overall declining trend.

Cost Cuts to Boost Margins: The industry is facing input cost inflation, transport and logistics costs, and the impact of tariffs. Industry players are constantly implementing cost-reduction actions, which are likely to help sustain margins in this scenario. The companies are focused on streamlining their operations and realigning around high-growth key markets or customer segments to enhance performance.

Prolonged Truck-Driver Shortage: The persistent driver crisis in the trucking industry is worsening supply-chain challenges across the United States. Driver scarcity issues limit trucking capacity, making it difficult for trucking companies to meet increased freight demand. American Trucking Associations’ chief economist, Bob Costello, expects the trucking industry to be short of more than 160,000 drivers by 2030.

Zacks Industry Rank Indicates Dull Prospects

The Zacks Transportation - Truck industry is a 12-stock group. The industry currently carries a Zacks Industry Rank #234, which places it in the bottom 2% of 243 Zacks industries.

The group’s Zacks Industry Rank, the average of the Zacks Rank of all member stocks, indicates murky near-term prospects. Our research shows that the top 50% of the Zacks-ranked industries outperforms the bottom 50% by a factor of more than 2 to 1.

The industry’s position in the bottom 50% of the Zacks-ranked industries is a result of a negative earnings outlook for the constituent companies in aggregate. Looking at the aggregate earnings estimate revisions, it appears that analysts are gradually losing confidence in this group’s earnings growth potential. The industry's earnings estimate for 2026 has decreased 30.9% on a year-over-year basis.

Before we present a few stocks from the industry that you may want to hold on to, let’s take a look at the industry’s recent stock market performance and the valuation picture.

Truck Industry Underperforms the SP 500 and the Sector

The Zacks Transportation-Truck industry has lagged the Zacks S&P 500 composite as well as the Transportation sector over the past year.

The industry has declined 3.7% over this period compared with the S&P 500's appreciation of 18.1% and the broader sector’s uptick of 1.4%.

Truck Industry's Current Valuation

Based on the trailing 12-month EV-to-EBITDA (enterprise value to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization), a commonly used multiple for valuing trucking stocks, the industry is currently trading at 14.37X compared with the S&P 500’s 18.99X. The figure is above the sector’s EV/EBITDA of 10.83X.

Over the past five years, the industry has traded as high as 16.3X and as low as 7.83X, with the median being 12.31X.

3 Transport Truck Stocks to Keep an Eye On

J.B. Hunt provides a broad range of transportation services to a diverse group of customers in the United States, Canada and Mexico. JBHT is benefiting from efforts to reward its shareholders through dividend payments and share repurchases.

Shares of JBHT have increased 11% in a year. JBHT currently carries a Zacks Rank of 3 (Hold). The company’s earnings have surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in two of the last four quarters (missing the mark on the other two occasions). The average beat is 3.4%.

You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.

Saia provides regional and interregional LTL services. The firm offers full value coverage, logistics services, distribution and consolidation, trade show, customs clearance, retail delivery, cross-border shipping to Mexico and Canada, and offshore shipping to Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

SAIA currently carries a Zacks Rank #3. The company’s earnings have surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in three of the last four quarters (missing the mark on the other occasion).

ArcBest provides freight transportation services and solutions. The company is based in Fort Smith, AR. ArcBest is being well-served by its efforts to control costs, improve productivity and enhance service quality.

The company expects its 2026 earnings per share to increase 37.9% on a year-over-year basis. Its earnings have missed the consensus mark in two of the last four quarters and beat the mark in the remaining two. The average beat is 5.8%. ArcBest currently carries a Zacks Rank #3.

Why Haven't You Looked at Zacks' Top Stocks?

Since 2000, our top stock-picking strategies have blown away the S&P's +7.7% average gain per year. Amazingly, they soared with average gains of +48.4%, +50.2% and +56.7% per year.
